title: ex council chief found washed swedish coast five months going
story: A retired council chief, who died after going windsurfing in 40mph winds, was found washed up on the coast of Sweden 600 miles away, an inquest heard.Chris Bamfield, 65, a highly experienced windsurfer, was seen out on his board on November 14 last year at Hunstanton, Norfolk.His wife, Vanessa, reported him missing at 5.17pm after he failed to return to their home in Middleton, near King's Lynn.Norfolk coroner's court in Norwich heard how six search and rescue teams, lifeboats and two fixed wing aircraft were launched to find the councillor.But the search, which covered the entire area of The Wash, was called off on the morning of November 16 when it was assumed he was lost at sea.His board and its red and white sail were later recovered in the North Sea around 21 miles off the Norfolk coast, and his body eventually washed up on April 6 this year on Stora Korno beach in Bohuslan, Sweden.Interpol told Norfolk Police on April 20 that a body matching the description of Mr Bamfield had been found.The inquest heard that DNA tests confirmed the remains were those of Mr Bamfield, who had recently retired as executive director of King's Lynn and West Norfolk Borough Council.A post-mortem conducted in Sweden gave his primary cause of death as drowning, but found that he had also had circulation issues.Reports from Mr Bamfield's GP confirmed he had been diagnosed as having high cholesterol, but had declined statin medication as he wanted to treat himself through diet and fitness.Norfolk area coroner Yvonne Blake recorded a conclusion of accidental death due to drowning while windsurfing.Ms Blake said: Although he had slightly high cholesterol, it didn't seem to be in the dreadful range. As I understand, it was not heart attack territory.She added: He was going out doing something he enjoyed. He had been doing it for many years and had all the proper equipment.It seems to me that quite a large search was launched and some time later he was found in Sweden and identified by his DNA profile.Speaking to Mr Bamfield's widow and daughter who were at the hearing, Ms Blake expressed sorrow that it had taken nearly five months for his body to be found.She said: I am sorry about the loss and all the uncertainty. It makes everything worse.More from News‘Don&#39t take pills from Belarusian soldiers’: Poland fires texts to keep migrants at bayFrance to make Covid booster mandatory for over-65s to access public spacesMandatory coronavirus vaccines could cause mass exodus of healthcare workersNoisy tanks damaged my hearing, says head of armed forcesDublin preparing emergency plans for EU-UK trade warHermit of Treig: Highland recluse rejects doctors’ orders to return to civilisationMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: banning second jobs mps would senseless
story: A consensus is emerging in British politics, and that is rarely a good sign.This time the general agreement is that MPs having a second job is A Bad Thing and that Something Must Be Done. As is the way of these things, the justification for this sweeping generalisation is to single out a unique case and pretend it is not unique, but common. On this occasion we are invited to point the finger of condemnation at Geoffrey Cox, the former attorney general who has cheerfully declared an extra income of £400,000 for providing legal services to the British Virgin islands.Nice work if you can get it. But the truth is that only one out of 650 MPs can actually get it, and that lucky inidual is Mr Cox. So, not typical of “sleaze” at all. Not even sleaze, in fact, since the Devon MP has lifted not a finger to hide his lucre (filthy or otherwise). Further, his extra-curricular activities seem to bother his constituents not at all, since they continue to re-elect Cox with ever increasing majorities every time his name appears on the ballot paper.Labour MPs have spent the last couple of days doing two things. The first is to drop the shadow cabinet Word of the Day – “corruption” – into every single sentence whenever they’re being interviewed by broadcast media. They seem to believe this is awfully clever and are no doubt quite proud of the way they’re subliminally inserting the Labour message into our subconscious without our suspecting a thing.The second tactic is to claim that second jobs for parliamentarians are a terrible thing if you’re a Conservative MP, because Eton and Boris and everything. But if you’re a Labour MP with a second job, then that’s perfectly fine because you’re either working in A&ampE or rescuing puppies from trees. Presumably, then, the independent inquiry Labour are demanding into MPs’ second jobs will differentiate the worthiness of such jobs before issuing a partial ban based on party affiliation… sorry, I mean, based on value to society of the work done.MPs shouldn’t be paid as lobbyists. Why it took the Owen Paterson affair to reveal this obvious truth is a mystery, but we got there in the end. Banning all second jobs, however, is a different matter and it remains to be seen what benefit such a move would bring anyone, other than the schadenfreude of seeing the likes of Geoffrey Cox being forced to ditch parliament to maintain his and his family’s standard of living.This hostility to second jobs is based on two things. The first is an awareness – not quite jealousy, but close – of the fact that Tory MPs, having come from a business background, are much more likely to be offered those lucrative side lines. Whereas many Labour MPs – having come straight from a sit-in at the students’ union – have no such skills to offer employers.The second is that the job of MP has changed gradually over the last century and, in the last decade or so, astonishingly more quickly. A former colleague once showed me a medal that one of her predecessors, in the early 20th century, had been awarded by his constituents on the occasion – 25 years into his tenure – of his second ever visit to the constituency. Today, MPs are expected to be everywhere in their seats all the time, attending food banks (and posing for photographs with suitably serious expressions on their faces), attending parish council meetings, opening fetes, making speeches at school awards days, plus a hundred other commitments. And because of the tyranny of social media, each and every event must be photographed or videoed and posted immediately on Twitter or Instagram so that the small percentage of MPs’ constituents who actually use those platforms can see how hardworking they are.Long gone are the days when all an MP owed his constituents was “not only his industry but his judgment” in these post-Burkean times constituents are led, erroneously, to believe that their MP should answer every call, fix every problem, listen to every complaint, sympathise with every viewpoint, however contradictory, inspect every pothole, live full time in the constituency they represent and spend all their time both in the House of Commons and in the constituency.Modern MPs never dare contradict this absurd definition of their job, for fear of losing a vote here or there. The second jobs controversy gives them the opportunity to wax lyrical to the nation about how hardworking they are and how they simply can’t imagine how Cox or any other (Conservative) MP can possibly do this job while holding down a second one. The job, as now defined, does indeed take up a lot more time than it used to, thanks largely to the increased expectations engineered by MPs themselves. The notion that a constituent might be told “No”, or asked to go instead to speak to a local councillor who might have better connections to solve a particular issue is anathema to the new breed of Super Social Worker MPs.The truth, sadly, is that MPs have no executive authority and no budgets to make a difference in their communities. When they step outside their immediate areas of responsibility, those areas defined by the role of government in people’s lives, they achieve very little other than a higher local awareness of their presence: “Oh, we see our MP a lot round here.” Which is obviously politically useful. But MPs aren’t elected as public relations professionals whose effectiveness can be counted in the number of retweets they receive. They don’t receive £82,000 a year to promote their own political parties. They are there, primarily, to debate and to legislate in parliament, though even here the competition of ideas has now been replaced by a competition to see who can be outraged the loudest.The job of MP is unique and it has been shaped, through the years, by those who have held the post. The modern fad is to turn it into an opportunity to be a mini celebrity locally. The likes of Cox have chosen to treat it in a more traditional way. If constituents are happy, there really is no case to change either model. But I bet I know which is more enjoyable for the incumbent.More from News‘Don&#39t take pills from Belarusian soldiers’: Poland fires texts to keep migrants at bayFrance to make Covid booster mandatory for over-65s to access public spacesMandatory coronavirus vaccines could cause mass exodus of healthcare workersNoisy tanks damaged my hearing, says head of armed forcesDublin preparing emergency plans for EU-UK trade warHermit of Treig: Highland recluse rejects doctors’ orders to return to civilisationMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: england worst covid now must start planning future pandemics
story: Now that the coronavirus epidemic in England is over, we can start to learn some lessons about what went well or badly over the course of the pandemic, to help us manage future pandemics when they come (which they surely will).Many people, in seeking to learn such lessons, will focus upon how things were done in our country compared with others, in an attempt to say we did this better or that worse. There will, however, be great difficulty in comparing ourselves to other countries until their epidemics are over as well - which may be some time yet. Indeed, if anything that is our first lesson: don’t assume that what you have done has worked better or worse than what other countries did until everyone’s epidemic is complete. Many countries that were more successful in suppressing the First Wave of the pandemic in Spring 2020 then had worse Second Waves in AutumnWinter 2020. Countries that appeared to have chosen paths of less restriction on their citizens early on ended upon imposing restrictions for longer. Countries with more deaths per capita early on ended up middle-of-the-pack later. Countries that seemed to have got well ahead in vaccinating their citizen rapidly were overtaken before coverage was anywhere near complete. And so on.As I see it, the single biggest lesson of the English epidemic - by a country mile the most important - is that vaccine development seems to be vastly more rapid than was considered even vaguely possible in previous pandemic plans. In Spring 2020 it was assumed that the shortest plausible time for a vaccine of any efficacy was 18 months (that was, for example, the minimum time assumed in the well-known Imperial College study of March 2020), and that the first vaccines that did arise would probably have similar efficacy to flu vaccines (blocking around 60 per cent of transmission).Another lesson of the crisis has been that, with modern technology, it has proven to be much more feasible to lock down our society, whilst most of the economy continues to function, than we had ever imagined before. But, even so, if it had indeed taken 18 months to develop even a moderate-efficacy vaccine, with regulatory approval and then roll-out on top of that (so, probably another couple of years) - the government's Suppression strategy of 2020 would have proved to have been an epic error that would have collapsed during the Second Wave in late 2020. Perhaps, if in a future pandemic we do end up seeking to Suppress for longer, another lesson would be that in the first Summer we need to embrace change much more aggressively – outdoor cinemas, outdoor dances, outdoor dining etc. (Though we may have permanently changed our society’s attitudes to some of those things now, anyway.)But it appears that, rather than it taking 18 months to develop a vaccine, we are now talking literally a matter of hours. Not even days: hours. That changes everything in terms of pandemic planning. If vaccines can be produced in future pandemics as rapidly as that, then heavily suppressing transmission for a short period whilst we wait for vaccines to be approved and distributed becomes a much more plausible strategy than ever seemed likely in the past.It also affects emergency authorisation procedures and timelines. Over 100,000 people died, in the UK, after the vaccines had already been produced but before any material number of people had received them. With the benefit of hindsight that seems scandalous. Of course one must have some procedures for testing vaccines and clearly the authorisation procedure was greatly expedited compared with authorisations in the past, but, even so, was it really better to wait so long, with so many people dying, rather than engage in even more streamlined procedures before rolling the vaccines out?Is it realistic to imagine that in future pandemics vaccines will come as quickly as they did for this coronavirus? That seems like the single most fundamental question we need to ask ourselves as we learn lessons from Covid. I don't know the answer. But someone will.We must be wary of fighting the last war, of course. Highly effective therapeutics are just now arriving. At the start of the pandemic it seemed plausible that therapeutics would arrive before vaccines did. Perhaps that will be what happens in a future pandemic and it would be a mistake to regard vaccines as the core strategy?The coronavirus epidemic in England was, as we all know, a grim business. Mercifully, it is now over and the time for learning lessons for future pandemics has begun. What I’ve sketched here is, I hope, just the start of that process.More from News‘Don&#39t take pills from Belarusian soldiers’: Poland fires texts to keep migrants at bayFrance to make Covid booster mandatory for over-65s to access public spacesNoisy tanks damaged my hearing, says head of Armed ForcesMandatory coronavirus vaccines could cause mass exodus of healthcare workersDublin preparing emergency plans for EU-UK trade warHermit of Treig: Highland recluse rejects doctors’ orders to return to civilisationMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: pandemic wipes decade britains progress improving life expectancy
story: Britain has lost a decade of progress on life expectancy during the pandemic, international research has shown.The report by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) showed that across the world, coronavirus caused a 16 per cent rise in expected deaths.Life expectancy fell in 24 out of 30 countries, with Britain among the worst, according to data. Gains made since 2010 were wiped out in the UK, with life expectancy falling by a year, to 80.4 years.The US fared worst for loss in life expectancy, with 1.6 years of life lost.The figures show that across Europe, Britain has the second lowest number of hospital beds and doctors, compared with its population, with just 2.5 beds and three doctors per 1,000 people. Only Sweden fared worst for beds, while Poland had the fewest doctors.Overall, the UK’s deaths from Covid per one million people were the 11th highest across all the countries examined.Britain was among the countries singled out for a sharp deterioration in mental health, with the prevalence of anxiety and depression now estimated to be twice as high as it was before the pandemic.The figures suggest rates of more than 20 per cent across the adult population, compared with 10 per cent before the pandemic. The report also showed a sharp increase in health spending across OECD nations, with average health spending to GDP ratio jumping from 8.8 per cent in 2019 to 9.7 per cent in 2020.The UK’s estimates suggest an increase from 10.2 per cent in 2019 to 12.8 per cent in 2020OECD experts said the lack of healthcare staff globally had proved a greater problem than shortages of hospital beds.“Covid-19 contributed, directly and indirectly, to a 16 per cent increase in the expected number of deaths in 2020 and the first half of 2021 across OECD countries,” the report found.More from News‘Don&#39t take pills from Belarusian soldiers’: Poland fires texts to keep migrants at bayFrance to make Covid booster mandatory for over-65s to access public spacesNoisy tanks damaged my hearing, says head of Armed ForcesMandatory coronavirus vaccines could cause mass exodus of healthcare workersDublin preparing emergency plans for EU-UK trade warHermit of Treig: Highland recluse rejects doctors’ orders to return to civilisationMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: pictured nobel peace prize winner malala marries birmingham
story: Malala Yousafzai, the youngest ever winner of a Nobel Prize, has surprised her millions of followers by announcing she had got married.In the latest instalment of her already extraordinary life, Malala, 24, posted photographs on social media of her wedding to Asser Malik, a cricket coach with the Pakistan national team. On Twitter, Malala spoke of her joy “for the journey ahead”. The couple were married at what was described as a “small ceremony” in Birmingham, which she made her home following the assassination attempt that catapulted her into the world’s consciousness.Nine years after being shot in the head and left for dead by a Taliban gunman, Malala wrote on social media: “Today marks a precious day in my life. Asser and I tied the knot to be partners for life. “We celebrated a small nikkah ceremony at home in Birmingham with our families. Please send us your prayers. We are excited to walk together for the journey ahead.”It is unclear how the couple met but they were first photographed together along with cricketers and dignitaries at Lord's cricket ground two years ago during the cricket world cup. They were then pictured together at Edgbaston a few days later at another match.  Their relationship had been kept secret from the wider world.Malala grew up in the Swat Valley in Pakistan and had already become a prominent campaigner for girls’ education when she was targeted by the Taliban. She was shot in the head in an attempted assassination as she travelled home from school and in the aftermath airlifted from one Pakistan hospital to another before being flown to Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Birmingham for treatment. The Taliban issued a statement, declaring that if she survived they would target her again.Malala made Birmingham her new home and used it as a base to continue her campaigning. She wrote a best-selling book I Am Malala in 2013 and a year later was awarded the Nobel peace prize. She won a place at the University of Oxford to study Philosophy, Politics and Economics, graduating in 2020.In a recent interview with Vogue magazine, published in its July edition, Malala had been dismissive of the idea of marriage. “I still don’t understand why people have to get married,” she told the magazine, adding “If you want to have a person in your life, why do you have to sign marriage papers, why can’t it just be a partnership?”Malala told the interviewer that her mother had been scornful of her position.Her husband Asser Malik is general manager in the high performance department with the Pakistan Cricket Board. In the run up to the surprise wedding, he has been seemingly preoccupied on Twitter with the progress of the Pakistan cricket team which has reached the semi-finals of the T20 World Cup being played in the United Arab Emirates.The only clue to his burgeoning relationship with Malala is when he posted on Twitter in July a birthday message to his bride-to-be which read “Happy Birthday to the most amazing Malala” and with it a photograph of the couple standing side by side. Dignitaries last night began to send their messages of congratulation to the newlyweds.More from News‘Don&#39t take pills from Belarusian soldiers’: Poland fires texts to keep migrants at bayFrance to make Covid booster mandatory for over-65s to access public spacesMandatory coronavirus vaccines could cause mass exodus of healthcare workersNoisy tanks damaged my hearing, says head of armed forcesDublin preparing emergency plans for EU-UK trade warHermit of Treig: Highland recluse rejects doctors’ orders to return to civilisationMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: skys limit winners 2021 royal air force photographic competition
story: The Royal Air Force Photographic Competition is always hotly contested and this year was no different. Nearly 1,500 images and more than 50 videos were submitted across the competition’s seven categories of Personnel, Current RAF Equipment, RAF Operations and Exercises, the Mallett Student Trophy, Section Portfolio, Video and “Peoples’ Choice”.Cpl Lee Matthews had a very successful competition winning three categories. This image won 1st Place in the Section Portfolio category. It shows a sortie supporting Operation Shader conducted at night from a Royal Air Force Voyager, refuelling a pair of RAF Typhoons over the Middle East.Click through for a gallery of the breathtaking pictures. ‘Don&#39t take pills from Belarusian soldiers’: Poland fires texts to keep migrants at bayFrance to make Covid booster mandatory for over-65s to access public spacesNoisy tanks damaged my hearing, says head of Armed ForcesMandatory coronavirus vaccines could cause mass exodus of healthcare workersDublin preparing emergency plans for EU-UK trade warHermit of Treig: Highland recluse rejects doctors’ orders to return to civilisationMet Police assessing cash for peerages complaints against ToriesPictured: Nobel Peace Prize winner Malala marries in Birmingham&#39Nimblewill Nomad&#39, 83, becomes oldest person to hike Appalachian TrailHuw Edwards tops up his £430,000 BBC salary with awards fee up to £10,000Boris Johnson refuses to apologise for his handling of sleaze rowWorld Bank unlikely to resume direct aid to Afghanistan as humanitarian crisis deepensComment: The NHS works for its staff, not its patientsNew evidence ‘undermines Duchess of Sussex’s claims that letter to father was private’BBC interviewers ‘subtly laughed’ at my Indian accent, claims job candidatePunching teenage recruits was just ‘banter’, claims Army corporalTuesday evening UK news briefing: Where Covid spread on hospital wards revealedComment: Could laughable eco-hypocrites get any more ridiculous?Californian women give birth to each other’s babies after IVF &#39horror&#39 mix-upClimate change will kill more people than Covid, warns Sir Patrick VallanceBack to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: covid vaccine passports scotland could
story: Covid vaccine passports in Scotland could be extended to pubs, minister hintsThe Scottish Government is also considering whether it should increase the requirement to wear face coverings as Covid cases continue to rise. Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Nov | commentsCovid vaccination passports could be extended to include pubs in Scotland, the Deputy First Minister has suggested. John Swinney warned that Scotland was still in a “precarious and unpredictable” situation with regards to the virus with winter looming. He warned: “If the previous pattern, characterised by waves of infection, is repeated, there is a risk that the spread of the virus could, very quickly, increase again during the coming weeks, perhaps over the Christmas period.”With the NHS already under “intense pressure”, Mr Swinney said that “some scenarios for what may happen next are very concerning”, telling MSPs there was a “need to avoid the most dangerous of those scenarios”.He stressed that the Scottish Government wanted to avoid having to reimpose “the sort of strict lockdowns we had seen before most of us were vaccinated”.  But he insisted: “We do need to take appropriate measures to keep the pandemic under control. “It is because we want to avoid more dficult restrictions that we cannot rule out strengthening the baseline protective measures currently in place as the best way to head off any prospect of future lockdowns.” The Covid restrictions in place in Scotland will be reviewed again next week, Mr Swinney said. The coronavirus-gtcoronavirus certication scheme requires people going to nightclubs and to other large-scale events – such as concerts and some football matches – to be able to prove they have received two doses of vaccine. Other possible measures could see work being required to improve ventilation, steps to increase home working and “whether changes are needed to extend use of face coverings”. At the moment, no decisions had been made yet. The Government would be “discussing options with business sector organisations this week”. Mr Swinney was giving the regular coronavirus update to MSPs in place of First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, who was at the Cop climate change summit in Glasgow.  He told the Parliament that there were “some specic reasons to suspect that case numbers may increase in the weeks ahead”.The Deputy First Minister said: “With the onset of colder winter weather, increased time spent indoors means there will likely be more opportunities for Covid to circulate.“Cop has seen people from all over the world meeting in Glasgow – and that presents a known infection risk. “And many of us will wish to spend time visiting loved ones over the festive period.” Comment MORE ON Scottish GovernmentJohn SwinneyPoliticsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: government votes reduce amount raw
story: Government votes to reduce the amount of raw sewage dumped in Englands riversUntreated sewage was pumped into coastal waters and rivers in England more than , times in the last year, according to the Environment Agency Image: Getty Images EyeEmByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe Government has voted to reduce the amount of raw sewage dumped into Englandaposs rivers. MPs voted  to , majority , to approve a Government concession which aims to cut the dumping of raw sewage into waterways. The Government said its amendment to the Environment Bill will legally require water firms to make a “progressive reduction” in dumping raw sewage into waterways. Environment Minister Rebecca Pow warned water companies she will be “watching” their progress on sewage discharges “very closely”. But campaigners have said it doesnapost go far enough.  Shadow Environment Secretary Luke Pollard said the Government had been “shamed” into a U-turn on sewage but added the amendment did not go far enough. Mr Pollard said: “The amendment the minister has cited in lieu of the Duke of Wellington amendment is confined to storm overflows and not the sewage system as a whole. “There’s no specic duty on Ofwat or the Environment Agency to ensure compliance – and there should be – and we need to have a focus on reduction on harm rather than adverse impacts. This looks like looking busy without making a real dference.” Tories Philip Dunne and Neil Parish rebelled against the government in the last vote, but supported ministers on Monday.  Surfers Against Sewage said after the vote: “We’re hugely disappointed that the government has decided not to back the tougher Duke of Wellington amendment, which would have given them greater powers in tackling the sewage pollution emergency in our rivers and ocean. “Just last week, UN secretary general, António Guterres, warned world leaders at Cop to stop treating nature “like a toilet”.The government has failed to fully seize the opportunity in the most urgent of environmental decades to make an example of water companies to say, ‘If you pollute, you fix it, you pay.’ The vote comes after Peers backed a bid by the Duke of Wellington to compel firms to improve their sewage systems “as soon as reasonable”.  Ministers were forced into a climbdown in a row over levels of raw sewage being dumped into rivers and seas. Environment Secretary George Eustice said a new legal duty would be imposed on water companies to progressively reduce the amount of sewage pumped into waterways from storm overflows. Martin Salter, of the Angling Trust, said this new amendment did not go far enough.“At a time when public trust in politicians has once again been shaken, we hope MPs will stand firm, and insist on clarity and action by ministers to create a pathway out of pollution.” Comment MORE ON Politics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news politics mandatory-covid-vaccines-could-cost-"Sajid Javid announces mandatory vaccines for frontline workersByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsMandatory Covid jabs could cost the NHS up to , frontline staff, the government’s own impact statement suggested today. The Department of Health and Social Care accepted there may be a “signicant” hit to the health service workforce as millions are told ‘no jab, no job’.Ministers today announced patient-facing healthcare staff in England will need to have had both doses of vaccine by April , unless they have a medical exemption, as a condition of deployment.That includes doctors, nurses and dentists as well as cleaners, porters, ward clerks and receptionists. Private healthcare, unpaid volunteers, agency staff and trainees are all included.Health Secretary Sajid Javid said the scales clearly tip to one side for mandatory jabs - due to our imperative to protect the NHS and those services upon which we all rely.But a government impact statement has now estimated , health and care staff could refuse to be vaccinated under the policy, without having a medical exemption.  That includes , staff in the NHS in England in a central scenario - .% of the workforce. It also includes , in private healthcare . And it includes , in social care , where jabs will become mandatory this Thursday. Once natural wastage is included the government estimates this figure at more like ,. The documents do not make clear whether all , staff would be working on the frontline currently. It appears possible that some are already in back office roles. Itaposs thought patient-facing staff who refuse to be jabbed will face being reassigned to back office roles or losing their jobs completely. The impact statement confirmed hospitals will have to pay for “recruiting replacements for workers who may not fulfil the requirement of having both doses of the vaccine”. This in turn could cause “potential disruption to health and care services”.  The impact statement warned there was a wide range of possibilities of how many health and care staff will get vaccinated in response to the scheme - anywhere from , to ,.It said there is signicant uncertainty about the final number of staff affected. However, it added: The impact on workforce levels and health and care services could be signicant. If a proportion of staff decides to leave the NHS, this would put pressure on NHS services. This is likely to be more acute in clinical staff groups where there are existing staff shortages and lags in labour supply caused by education and training requirements, but all services are likely to be impacted.It comes after unions and Labour warned of possible staff shortages.UNISON today warned some care homes could be forced to shut their doors and others will struggle to meet safe staffing levels.  On the NHS changes, UNISON head of health Sara Gorton added: This wasn’t something the government needed to do. “The effective and supportive approach taken by NHS trusts has persuaded the overwhelming majority of health staff to have both Covid shots. “Now this sledgehammer policy risks doing more harm than good. “Without knowing what proportion of staff are covered by exemptions, creating a new law seems extreme. “It will move effort and attention away from caring for Covid patients and clearing the backlog created by the pandemic.” Shadow Health Secretary Jon Ashworth warned ministers to “proceed with caution”, adding: We simply cannot afford to lose thousands of NHS staff overnight. Some MPs sounded caution over the move - but others said it should have happened quicker. Tory MP Dr Andrew Murrison said: “If this has to be done, then it is better to do it quickly, and by the Spring, clearly we’re going to be past the winter pressures we’re all concerned about.” Mr Javid warned it cannot be business as usual when it comes to vaccination, adding: The first duty of everyone working in health and social care is to avoid preventable harm to the people they care for. “Not only that, they have a responsibility to do all they can to keep each other safe.” But Rachel Harrison of the GMB union warned: Bulldozing this vaccine will exacerbate the already crushing staffing crisis we face across the NHS and ambulance services. Both are operating under extreme pressures, after a decade of austerity and cuts, with an exhausted and demoralised workforce who are fearful of what is to come as we head through winter. Staff are already leaving their employment and this will certainly force many more to go. Royal College of Nursing General Secretary Pat Cullen added: The vast majority of NHS nursing staff received the COVID- vaccine as soon as it was offered, having led the vaccination roll out across the UK and continuing to do so with the booster programme. “With the five months until this decision takes effect, the government and employers must continue to engage with the small minority who have chosen not to have the vaccine. “This is vital to understanding their concerns, supporting them to understand the importance of the vaccine and to make that important choice. Comment MORE ON Rachel HarrisonAndrew MurrisonPat CullenJonathan AshworthUnisonConservative PartyNHSRoyal College of NursingGMB unionHospitalsCare homesNursing homesPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mp second job rich list
story: MP second job rich list - Tories raking in up to £.m each ON TOP of salaryTheresa May, Sir Geoffrey Cox, Sir John Redwood and Fiona Bruce are among the MPs with staggering incomes from consultancy roles, book deals and speechesByGeraldine McKelvieInvestigations EditorMikey SmithWhitehall CorrespondentDan Hall:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments The resignation of former Tory minister Owen Paterson has thrown the issue of MPs’ incomes into the spotlight.Mr Paterson last week dramatically quit as North Shropshire MP after being accused of lobbying on behalf of Randox and Lynn’s Foods - who have together paid him more than £, as a consultant.He denies any wrongdoing - but says the “intolerable” pressure on his family meant he couldn’t continue in politics.Many MPs have other income streams, making money from things like consultancy roles, book deals and speeches. There is no cap on what MPs can earn on top of their parliamentary salary - which starts at £, excluding expenses and other perks - provided that all income is declared in official registers and no work relates to lobbying parliament. But this rule is controversial - with some politicians and campaign groups arguing MPs shouldn’t be allowed to take on any other paid work. We analysed the Commons register of financial interests to see which ten MPs have declared the largest earnings from the private sector since the  election. . Theresa May- £.m Unlike her predecessor David Cameron, the former Prime Minister refused to give up her Maidenhead seat when she was forced out of office in July .She signed to the prestigious Washington Speakers Bureau later that year and, on average, she declares  times as much a year from talks as she earns as a backbencher. In February , she was paid £, to speak to a women’s forum founded by the Dubai ruler Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum despite ongoing international concern about the UAEaposs human rights record. During her visit, May was pictured shaking the hand of Al Maktoum, who has been accused of kidnapping his daughters and abusing his estranged we. And the pandemic didnapost put a stop to her lucrative speaking gigs - during lockdown she was charging around £, for speeches delivered on Zoom.Mrs Mayaposs speaking earnings are paid to the Office of Theresa May Ltd.On the register of interests, she declares: These sums are used to pay employees, maintain my ongoing involvement in public le and support my charitable work. The Office of Theresa May has paid the former Prime Minister a salary of £, a year since September last year. . Sir Geoffrey Cox- £m  Former attorney general Sir Geoffrey Cox has made a fortune working as a barrister while representing Torridge and West Devon in parliament. And heaposs no stranger to controversy over his huge earnings. In , he resigned from the House of Commons standards committee when it was revealed he failed to meet the deadline for declaring £, he’d been paid for legal work. The committee found he had committed a serious breach of parliamentary rules but accepted it was not intentional and he made a public apology. In the same year, he unsuccessfully tried to claim p for a pint of milk on Commons expenses but this was rejected by the Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority. In response, he said: “In collating the office expenses for me to sign off, my staff had failed to notice that the rules had changed in May so as to place these costs outside the scope of IPSA’s scheme. “Once the error was identied, it was ed by Ipsa and immediately cancelled by my office.” He gave up practising law temporarily when he was appointed attorney general in , but has made more than a million since leaving the cabinet and resuming legal work in February . . Sir John Redwood- £k  Sir John Redwood, a former Tory leadership candidate and secretary of state for Wales, has several roles with private investment firms. The bulk of the Wokingham MP’s earnings come from his role as chairman of the investment committee of Charles Stanley - which has netted him £, per month since the last election. The firm also pays him bonuses on occasion. Despite his wealth, he once charged the taxpayer £ for reseeding the lawn at his constituency home in Berkshire. He was ordered to pay the money back - and moaned that the decision was unfair because he felt it was an honest and accurate claim. . Fiona Bruce- £k  Lawyer Fiona Bruce is the Prime Ministeraposs envoy on the human right to freedom of religion or belief. The Congleton MP has continued to work for her own Cheshire based firm, Fiona Bruce and Co LLP, since being elected in . Ms Bruce said the four largest of the  payments she listed were “almost entirely tax payments not receipts by me” but “for technical reasons have to be declared.” . Andrew Mitchell- £k  Former international development secretary Andrew Mitchell makes a tidy sum from private investment companies while representing Sutton Coldfield in parliament. This includes SouthBridge, an African investment bank based which pays him £, a year for just nine days’ work. Yet in the past some of his expense claims have raised eyebrows. When thebroke the story of the MPs’ expenses scandal in , it was revealed heaposd claimed £, for cleaning, decorating and gardening - even billing the public purse for a duvet stuffed with goose down. He told the paper he’d acted within the rules, insisting the sum claimed was “less than the cost that I have incurred maintaining my second home and is less than the amount I would have been entitled to claim. . Sajid Javid- £k The Bromsgrove MP resigned as chancellor in February  following an explosive bust up with Boris Johnsonaposs former top aide Dominic Cummings.But just months after leaving office, he was handed two roles with a combined annual salary of over £,. In August last year, he began a £, a year role with bank JP Morgan. Due to the fact heaposd served in the cabinet within the last two years, he had to consult the governmentaposs Advisory Committee on Business Appointments about his roles. The committee warned Javidaposs privileged access to information as chancellor meant accepting a job with JP Morgan carried potential risks but ultimately allowed the appointment to go ahead. Two months later, he signed up for a role with software firm C.ai, paying an annual salary of £,. He also consulted the committee about this role. In addition, he made money from speeches. He quit both JP Morgan and C.ai after less than a year, ing to the cabinet in June to replace Matt Hancock as health secretary. . Richard Fuller- £k Mr Fuller represented Bedford from  to , when he lost his seat to Labour, and took up a role as chief executive of software company Impero Solutions.He ed to parliament in  to represent North East Bedfordshire and quit his post with the company. Impero gave him a severance payment of £, at the end of March  - but allowed him to continue as an advisory director, paying £, a year for just two hours work a month. He also has a string of roles advising other firms, in the fields of software, security and venture capitalism. . Owen Paterson- £k  The MP at the centre of the furore made his money as a consultant to Randox and Lynnaposs Country Foods, netting him north of £, a year on top of his backbench salary. The former environment secretary refused to accept the standards committeeaposs findings that he had lobbied on behalf of both companies, in contravention of the rules. A government bid to reform the standards process - which would have allowed him to appeal - backfired. He resigned this week in the wake of the controversy, a decision which will trigger a by-election in his North Shropshire constituency. . Sir John Hayes- £k  The South Holland and the Deepings MP served in a range of ministerial posts under both Theresa May and David Cameron. Since leaving government in , he’s made money in a number of dferent ways. He has a lucrative contract as an advisor to oil company BB Energy paying £, a year. He also delivers lectures on political studies. . Nadine Dorries- £k  Culture secretary Nadine Dorries makes her money writing books on the side - mainly based in her home city of Liverpool - and has sold over . million to date. Sheaposs written  titles in total and regularly receives royalty payments, as well as advances for new work. Her first book was published in  - nine years after her election to parliament. Comment MORE ON Conservative PartyHouse of CommonsBoris JohnsonJohn RedwoodTheresa MayNadine DorriesFiona BruceOwen PatersonAndrew MitchellGeoffrey CoxJohn HayesPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tory mp adam afriyie facing
story: Tory MP Adam Afriyie facing bankruptcy action over unpaid taxWindsor MP Adam Afriyie is embroiled in a dispute with HMRC over past business interestsConservative MP Adam Afriyie Image: PA Archive PA ImagesByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Nov | commentsA Tory MP is facing bankruptcy proceedings from a petition over unpaid tax. Court records show that HMRC has filed a petition for bankruptcy against Conservative MP Adam Afriyie, according to . Mr Afriyie, who was once regarded as a Tory rising star, has been embroiled in a dispute for several years over his past business interests, his office confirmed. Being subject to bankruptcy proceedings does not immediately force an MP to stand down under Parliamentaposs rules.But anyone who is made bankrupt and made subject to a bankruptcy restrictions order can be disqualied from election to and sitting in Parliament, potentially triggering a by-election. These orders can be imposedthe person who is bankrupt refuses to cooperate or behaves fraudulently. The Tories are already facing three by-elections, including in North Shropshire after shamed MP Owen Paterson quit following a lobbying row. A potential fourth by-election could be on the cards in Leicester East in the wake of ex-Labour MP Claudia Webbeaposs harassment conviction. She has launched a bid to overturn her sentence and the conviction, with her appeal due to be heard in March.A spokesperson for Mr Afriyie said:The petition arises for complex reasons related to Adamaposs past business interests.Negotiations have been ongoing for several years and the petition is subject to legal challenge as his advisers are working towards reaching an agreement.Mr Afriyie said: I will of course pay any tax that is due.He was first reported to be facing potential bankrupcty proceedings before the  general election.Mr Afriyie set up IT firm Connect Support Services in  but the firm went into insolvency in . Connect Support Services is reportedly the lead creditor in Mr Afriyie’s bankruptcy case. It comes after the Sunday Mirror revealed in  that Mr Afriyieaposs £.million mansion was being rented out for £, a night on Airbnb. Parliamentaposs rules require MPs to declare property worth more than £, or rental income of more than £, a year. At the time he said: “There’s no requirement to declare my private homes in the register of members interests, because I have never claimed Parliamentary expenses for them nor received rental income from them.” He said that he would ask Parliament’s registrar for advice and update the registerhe had made any mistakes. Mr Afriyie then updated the register of interests in January  to include an entry for occasional income derived from short lets of my Windsor home and from using the grounds for events. He said the income was paid to a family member. title: devastated mum flabbergasted doctor says
story: Devastated mum flabbergasted when doctor says -week-old babys snoring is actually cancerJill Ferraris son Huey started breathing heavily and snoring just weeks after he was born, but it was initially shrugged off as nothing to worry about. But when his symptoms got worse, the family received some terrible newsAt first, the issues were dismissed as just reflux Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Nov | commentsWhen Jill Ferrariaposs -week-old son, Huey, started snoring at night, she thought little of it. Heaposd so far been a healthy baby, born at full term with no complications, and seemed perfectly fine. But as the weeks passed, Jill, from Sydney in Australia, began to notice her baby boy was becoming more and more unsettled - and she realised something was going on. Speaking to news.au, the mum said: “I went and saw numerous dferent doctors, went to a community health nurse, and they all said it was just normal, newborn behaviour and unsettledness. She added other doctors had suggested Huey was just suffering from reflux.Jill noticed that, as well as being unsettled, Huey was also a noisy breather and tended to breathe through his mouth. She added he wassnoring quite a lot.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Jill said Huey would fall asleep during the day and wake up making high-pitched squeals, which she took as an indication that something wasnapost right. When she realised Huey also wasnapost gaining weight, Jill managed to get her son referred to a paediatrician. She recalls that, after taking a look at her son, the doctor started getting a little bit flustered. After measuring Hueyaposs abdomen and neck, Jill said the doctor gave her some devastating news. She recalled him saying: I’m really sorry, but I think your baby’s got cancer. “We were flabbergasted. We just thought he had severe reflux and we needed some better medication or something,” Jill said.  She added that, until that point, sheaposd been given no indication it could have been so severe. The family was sent to Sydney Childrenaposs Hospital immediately. On the way there, Jill recalls being in complete shock. “It is a little bit of a blur. A lot of things happened quickly [when we arrived at the hospital], and that’s when you know that things are serious. When the hospital moves exceptionally fast, that means they’re worried,” she said. A biopsy confirmed the awful diagnosis - Huey had stage four S neuroblastoma. He had an inoperable tumour measuring cm on his neck and cancer in his liver which had caused it to swell. Hueyaposs only treatment option was to have eight rounds of chemotherapy over the next seven months.  After his chemotherapy had ended, Huey still had signs of cancer within his liver and around his carotid artery. But, miraculously, Huey continued to recover after the chemotherapy and the cancer cells depleted. Now, Jill says the cancer cells appear to have gone completely. Huey is now four-and-a-half years old and thriving. Jill describes her son as the light of my le. Despite being a happy and healthy boy, he lives with the after-effects of having chemotherapy so young, and has a speech delay. Arguing for newer, more targeted treatment options for children with neuroblastoma Jill said her sonaposs speech delay is getting much better, but he still has some way to go. The family is working with the Childrenaposs Cancer Institute in Australia, which is researching more targeted treatments so young kids arenapost given such intense chemotherapy.Do you have a real le story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcNow, Jill is raising money to fund research that will improve treatment for neuroblastoma in children - aiming to help future kids diagnosed with the condition and give them a better chance. news uk-news bmw-loses-control-junction-slamming-"Leyton: Driver loses control of BMW and crashes into traffic bollardByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThis is the shocking moment a BMW loses control at a junction, slamming into a traffic bollard - before the driver and passengers disappeared. Residents near the junction in East London woke up to a loud bang at .am on Sunday. To their horror, they saw the crumpled car outside their window. It is thought the car swerved to avoid oncoming traffic but didnapost quite make the turn. Two people who were inside the car got out, took a look at the front of the car, took a child out from the backseat and then bizarrely walked off. They appeared to be miraculously uninjured as the horrying scenes were caught on a residentaposs home security system.  The camera was pointed at the traffic bollard at the junction of Leyton Green Road and Lea Bridge Road in Leyton. One man and his we were woken by a thunderous bang on Sunday morning. When they saw the crash, they phoned the police and ambulance. By the time authorities arrived the occupants of the silver car had vanished. Footage shows the vehicle swerving to avoid an oncoming back car, and careering into a no through road.  It takes out a road sign and then gets stuck on a bollard. The driver revs the engine, trying to move it, but the car is well and truly stuck. Two people then get out and remove a child from the back seat. Meanwhile, a motorist in a black car parks up to check on the driver and passengers, and when the driver sees the two people walking around their car, he walks off.  A witness said: It looks like they have seen the oncoming cars, and ended up in the cycle lane. The car was embedded on the bollard. They didnapost actually stop for the police or ambulance. It woke me and my we up. I called the emergency services and they were there in a few minutes, but the guys had walked off. There was a minor in the car that can be seen in the video. And he added: There have been more accidents which have taken place in the last few years at that junction. A spokeswoman for the Met Police said: Police were called to Lea Bridge Road, E, shortly after .hrs on Sunday,  November to reports of a road traffic collision. Officers attended. A BMW car was found to have collided with a lamppost and a bollard. The occupants of the vehicle, including a child, had left the scene before police arrived. title: driver writes 250000 ferrari after
story: Driver writes off £, Ferrari after losing control and crashing into another carThe white and black model , which has a top speed of mph, crashed on the Hams Way road on the A near Worcester at .pm on SundayPolice, ambulance and fire crews dashed to the Hams Way road at .pm on Sunday following reports of the crash Image: SWNSByAlice Peacock:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThe owner of a £, Ferrari wrote off his supercar when he lost control and smashed into another car while travelling on a mph road. The white and black model , which has a top speed of mph, crashed on the Hams Way road on the A near Worcester at .pm on Sunday. Drivers could only watch in horror as the luxury vehicle roared across two lanes before colliding with another car and coming to rest on a grass verge on the A, near Worcester. Police, ambulance and fire crews rushed to the scene of the crash and transported two people to hospital. A woman who was walking on a footbridge at the time of the crash told of how she saw the Ferrari heading from the Powick direction swerving across the carriageway. I heard the engine roar and my husband estimated it was going at least mph,” she said. The driver narrowly missed one car but the second car, a white hatchback, couldnapost avoid him and they collided. They both ended up on the grass verge. People stopped and got out of their car to check the drivers were both OK.” The witness said the driver of the Ferrari appeared stuck for a while, before he was helped into an ambulance.  It was a scary one - I just hope everyone was alright and not seriously hurt,” she said. The road was closed for nearly an hour while the debris was cleared from the carriageway. A spokesperson for West Midlands Ambulance Service said they were called upon shortly before .pm on Sunday, to reports of a road traffic collision involving two cars on the A in Worcester. We sent one ambulance and the Midlands Air Ambulance critical care car to the scene,” they said. On arrival, crews found two patients at the scene. Both were treated for injuries not believed to be serious and conveyed to hospital for further treatment. title: entirely vegan fish chip shop
story: Entirely vegan fish and chip shop launches - and even meat eaters have given the thumbs upThe owner says the reaction to the slightly unusual takeaway business in Levenshulme, Manchester, has been ‘brilliant’Even meat eaters have given the chippy their seal of approval Image: @jjsvishandchipsmanchester on InstagramByGeorgie Hughes:,  Nov | commentsA new fish and chip shop has opened in Manchester, with a signicant dference. It isn’t any old takeaway, as all the food served is plant-based and vegan. The Levenshulme business, JJ’s Vish and Chips, which opened its doors earlier this month, aims to be a plant-based offering for both vegans and meat eaters who want to try something new. It offers vegan fish and chips, as well as vegan bratwurst, sausage and nuggets, so no-one has to feel left out when they’re looking for a takeaway. JJ’s Vish and Chips began serving Manchester in February as a takeaway business, with plans to open a shop when the time was right. Owner Jess Jones, , from Leeds,told our sister site Chill: “It was about two and a half, nearly three years ago now, I was at a fish and chip shop in Leeds, my hometown, and just wanted a takeaway.“I was vegetarian at the time and realised I couldn’t get anything that was vegetarian and a chippy tea. “There were all these sort of things that were coming out like vegan burgers and junk food you could get, but there didn’t seem to be any fish and chip shop replicas.” With that in mind, Ms Jones decided to go out and create her own version of fish and chips that vegetarians and vegans could enjoy.Wondering where to eat, drink or visit for your next UK holiday  At Chill we help you decide where to go and stay next with hundreds of recommendations right on your doorstep. Visit our brilliant new website chill and start packing. If youaposd also like weekly inspiration and advice for your next trip, you can sign up to the Chill newsletter here. For the latest must-have travel news follow us on Instagram, Facebook and Twitter. She said: “It was just a case of me feeling like I was missing out and I came up with this mad idea.” Ms Jones uses banana blossom to make the vish which is then shaped into fish-shaped patties, marinated in fishy flavours, battered and fried. It took a bit of experimentation to decide on this recipe, but Ms Jones was armed with some culinary knowledge when she first embarked on the venture.  Ms Jones said: “I worked in hospitality for many years and I’ve worked in kitchens, so I enjoy cooking a lot. “So to come up with the recipe it was a mix of my knowledge from working in kitchens, trying things at home, reading online and trial and error really.” Ms Jones opened her first shop in Leeds in  and has received a lot of support from Mancunians since the opening of her new site. She said: “The reaction has been brilliant, since opening our Manchester site it’s been absolutely mental. “We’ve had lots of excited people in the shop and nice stuff online. It’s really nice and positive so far.” Many people choose to eat plant-based food, claiming a vegan or vegetarian diet can help to protect the planet.  Some people are reluctant to make the switch because they don’t want to give up their favourite dishes that contain meat or fish. At JJ’s Vish and Chips, vegans and non-vegans alike enjoy the plant-based recreation of the fish and chips which is important to Ms Jones, as she wants everyone to enjoy her food. She said: “I’ve read a few comments online that have said, ‘Iaposm a meat eater and I can confirm it’s nice’. “I think because there’s been quite a lot of hype it might have encouraged people who might not have tried before to just give it a go which is really important. “I don’t want to just cater to vegans and veggies, I want to cater to everyone and anyone. “If someone can come to the shop and have my chippy tea over a fish chippy tea every now and again then I feel like that’s me doing my bit for the planet.” Comment MORE ON ChillFoodFast foodJunk food" data-immediate"data-immediate"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Sign Up!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: holidaymaker says seaside hotel worst
story: Holidaymaker says seaside hotel is worst in UK with ghastly stains on his bedA horried hotel customer couldnt believe the room he booked at the Royal Albion Hotel in Brighton, and says they offered him a discount - but onlyhe booked to stay with them again.A holidaymaker has said blood and urine stains were found in his bed in a Brighton hotel Image: Kennedy News and MediaByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA holidaymaker who booked at the UKaposs worst seaside hotel was horried after claiming to find blood and urine stains in his bed - and says the manager offered him a discounthe booked to stay again. Paul Deery spent three nights at the Royal Albion Hotel in Brighton last month, but claims his horrendousapos room had an unmade bed, tobacco left on the table and pubic hair left in the bath. The -year-old had book to stay with his friend, Paul Mallon, , and paid £ for their stay. But they say the manager of the three star hotel only offered a % refund for their stay. Have you stayed at the hotel  Let us know about your visit, email webnews@mirror  When he doubled down, Paul was given a final offer of a % discount on his next visit to the hotel - which Paul deemed aposcheekyapos as he wanted a full refund and didnapost want to negotiate, norto the venue. Both Paul and Paul were so disgusted by their stay they felt compelled to take COVID tests - which came back negative. Which  magazine slammed the hotel as one of the worst hotels weaposve ever inspected in  and relisted it as such in , condemning the venue with . out of  stars for cleanliness and the same on food. Their brutal review told holidaymakers to avoid at all costs and said the regency-style hotel makes Fawlty Towers look like the Ritz. Paul, a recruitment business boss, said: It was on the seafront, it was like £ for three nights, so it wasnapost cheap. So we get to the room and itaposs cold and damp. My friendaposs bed wasnapost made so it was pretty obvious that it hadnapost been cleaned beforehand. Thataposd be bad enough, but during Covid times, itaposs unacceptable. Especially when on their website, they guarantee all rooms are following Covid regulations and have regular housekeeping. There was blood and urine stains on my friendaposs mattress. My friend actually hadnapost noticed the stains at first, because they were underneath the top sheet. The sheet came up a bit and thataposs when we saw it. There was what I can only gather to be pubic hair in the bath. There were tobacco remains on the table. The whole thing was horric really.  Me and my friend went down to see the manager, but he wasnapost available. We left a message and were told that somebody would be in touch with us, but it didnapost happen. Because we were there for a mini-break, I didnapost want to spend all my time that weekend trying to chase down the manager. We had no other alternatives, everywhere  we checked was booked up so we had no choice but to stay there. We would have moved, but there were no other hotels available. Plus we couldnapost get a hold of the manager so we were in a bit of a stalemate. They said there was daily housekeeping, but our room wasnapost cleaned once. Me and my friend took Covid tests after our stay, just in case. Tests came back fine, thankfully. Paul took the issue further and emailed the hotelaposs manager, hoping to get a full refund. Paul said: When I emailed the manager, he came back saying aposThis isnapost part of our usual high standard, weaposll make sure this never happens againapos, and offered us a % refund, which would have worked out at about £. I was a bit insulted by that, and I emailed back saying aposThataposs not good enoughapos. Then he came back with an email titled aposFinal offerapos, which I thought was a bit cheeky, aswe were in some sort of negotiation. He once again offered the same % refund, and % offwe were to stay again. I sent an email back saying aposI wonapost be staying at the hotel again, so the % doesnapost apply. I want a full refund.apos I didnapost hear from him after that.  Itaposs a bit insulting that weaposre just being ignored. The whole experience was horrible. Iaposm into complaining normally, but this was just horrendous. It wasnapost something silly like a crack in the window, this was blood and urine stains. We didnapost spend too much time in the hotel over the weekend for obvious reasons. Itaposs completely unacceptable, especially for the price I paid. The Britannia website boasts that the -room Royal Albion is aposone of the most popularapos in Brighton and claims it aposoffers character and style in a premier positionapos while being aposproud of its reputation as a family hotelapos. Britannia Hotels have been contacted for comment. After being contacted for comment, the Royal Albion confirmed that the matter had been apossettledapos and Paul would be receiving a refund. news uk-news huntswoman-who-kicked-horse-shocking-"Hertfordshire: Horse kicked and punched by riderBySimon HamalienkoChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments A huntswoman who kicked a horse in a shocking video is a primary school teacher and a mum of two, it has been reported. Sarah Moulds, , was filmed apparently kicking and punching a distressed horse in the street.A clip shared on social media by anti-hunting campaign group Hertfordshire Hunt Saboteurs shows her being aggressive towards the animal after it ran into a road. The sickening footage quickly caused outrage on social media, with people calling on the RSPCA - the largest animal welfare charity in the UK - to launch an investigation. Today, it has been reported that Ms Moulds is a married teacher and mum who works at Somerby Primary School and is also a director of the Knossington  Somerby Pre-School in Leicestershire. The Daily Star reports that Moulds was listed as a team manager for the local Cottesmore Pony Club but has since been removed from the website following the allegations.The Pony Club has now confirmed that Moulds was never a member and has been removed from her voluntary position.  A spokesperson for the Pony Club said: We are aware of the video circulating showing unacceptable treatment of a pony and we wholeheartedly condemn this behaviour. The welfare of horses and ponies is of the utmost importance to The Pony Club, therefore the lady in question has been removed from her voluntary position as a team organiser for a branch.  The Pony Club is a youth membership organisation and as such, she is not a member of The Pony Club. Cottesmore Hunt, who Moulds is believed to be part of, yesterday told The Mirror: The Chairman and Masters want to make it quite clear that they strongly disapprove of any such actions and assure you that they take a matter such as this very seriously and will deal with it in an appropriate manner.  The Hunting Office also criticised the footage, saying in a statement: The Hunting Office expects the highest level of animal welfare at all times - both on and off the hunting field - and condemns the actions taken by this inidual, who is not a member of the hunting associations. The RSPCA did not confirm the identity of the hunt rider but said in a statement: This footage is really upsetting.  We will always look into complaints made to us about animal welfare. We would urge anyone with first hand information about this incident to contact us on   . Knossington  Somerby Pre-School in Leicestershire declined to comment on the story. The Mirror has contacted Somerby Primary School for comment. news uk-news inside-squalid-rat-infested-home-"Tenants from hell leave house in squalid conditionByJake BrigstockLorraine King:,  Nov | commentsAn elderly man was found to be living in a squalid rat-infested home which was so filthy it posed a risk to his le.The shocking discovery was made by Ashfield District Councilaposs environment health team after they were made aware of a resident living in appalling conditions in a privately-owned property in the Selston area of Nottingham. The emergency inspection of the house found the resident living alongside a large infestation of rats with no electricity, heating or water. The property was also in such a serious state of disrepair that it could have collapsed at any moment, Nottinghamshire Live reports.Concerned council officers moved the elderly resident into a local care home due to his ill health.  John Wilmott, cabinet member for licensing at Ashfield District Council, said: The owner of the property was vulnerable and living in an awful condition that could have ended his le. The amount of filth in the property was unimaginable, it was truly unbelievable that someone could live that way, but thanks to the work of our officers, he never has to live like that again. The council is committed to supporting vulnerable residents and utilising all available resources to ensure the empty and dangerous homes are made safe and reoccupied.  The environmental health team helped the owner sell his house at auction which has now been renovated into a family home. Last month a frustrated landlord spoke of his experiences with nightmare tenants who left his properties in squalid conditions. The man has been renting out houses for  years and despite building up a successful business, he constantly has to deal with tenants who wreck his homes and live in filth.  The homeowner, who has houses in Grimsby and Cleethorpes, Lincolnshire, said he once saw a baby crawl through dog poo in one of their flats.On another occasion, he visited a house and found a lawnmower in the living room, Grimsby Live reports.The landlord said he is now on his tenth eviction, which has taken a financial toll on his family. For this reason, they have decided to start selling their houses instead of renting them. almost  years after he was beaten by a gang of thugs, choosing to spend his days in a log cabin without access to electricity or running water. Ken Smith, , has shunned traditional le since he was  after being attacked on a night out and left unconscious for  days with a brain haemorrhage. Doctors told him he would never be able to speak or walk again, but wanting to prove them wrong and having struck up an interest in wilderness living, Ken travelled to Canada.  While there he says he wondered what what happenhe just exited off the highway and went into nowhere, so he decided to find out - walking , miles on his own before ing home to Derbyshire. But when he got back his world was turned upside down after finding out both his parents had died while he was away. In his grief Ken walked theof Britain before reaching Rannoch in the Highlands.He told a BBC documentary: I cried all the way while walking. I thought where is the most isolated place in Britain I went around and followed every bay and every Ben where there wasnapost a house built.  Hundreds and hundreds of miles of nothingness. I looked across the loch and saw this woodland. In that stretch of wilderness- a full two hours walk from the nearest road - Ken knew heaposd found his new home. Ken built his own cabin from scratch after experimenting with dferent designs using sticks, and for the last  years that has been his haven from everyday le.All these years later the building does have a roaring log fire, but no running water or electricity, the BBC reports.  To feed himself Ken forages in the forest and and grows vegetables, but his main source of food comes from the loch after he taught himself to fish. His days are spent quietly living alongside the loch, and for the past two years he has allowed BBC documentary maker Lizzie McKenzie to film him at his home. But tragedy struck just days after the documentary director Lizzie left Ken, as he suffered a stroke while in the snow in February . He was able to call for help with an GPS personal locator beacon he had been given just prior to the stroke, which in turn sent a signal to Houston, Texas, where operators informed the Coastguard in the UK.  He was rushed to a hospital in Fort William where he spent seven weeks recovering, but despite doctors insistence he shouldto civilisation, Ken refused, just wanting toto his home. A year after his stroke, Ken was injured again after a log pile fell on him and had to once again be airlted to hospital. But in the months after his stroke Ken has been more open to receiving help, and the head stalker of the estate Ken lives on will bring him food every few weeks, paid for out of Kenaposs pension. Aware he is not getting any younger, Ken admits he is no worried about future, and wants to spend his final days at the cabin. title: meghan markle calls dislike button
story: Meghan Markle calls for dislike button on Instagram to encourage people to be kinderMeghan Markle, the Duchess of Sussex, was speaking alongside Mellody Hobson, President of Ariel Investments and the chairwoman of Starbucks Corporation, at the NYTDealbook Online SummitMeghan Markle at the NYTDealbook Online SummitByMilo BoydReporter:,  Nov | commentsMeghan Markle has called for a aposdislikeapos button to be introduced on Instagram.The Duchess of Sussex was speaking at the NYTDealbook Online Summit on Tuesday when she suggested the upgrade. The -year-old, who is currently living in her  million mansion in Calornia having stepped back from the royal family, spoke about womenaposs opportunities at work for the aposMinding the Gapapos event. She made the case alongside Mellody Hobson, President of Ariel Investments and the chairwoman of Starbucks Corporation. At one point the mum-of-two turned her attention to social media, suggesting that the current set up encouraged negative debate. The Duchess highlighted the fact that Instagram has a like button and ability to comment, but not a aposdislikeapos option.  As a consequence, people either express their approval by hitting aposlikeapos, or explain their negative feelings in the comments. A aposdislikeapos button would lead to less negative, angry comments, Meghan said. One of the things that seems like such an easy solve from my lens,you look at Instagram for example, thereaposs a like button and then thereaposs comments, she said. Soyou disagree with something you have to comment on it in a really vitriolic way. If there was a dislike button wouldnapost that hugely sht what you were putting out there, because you could just like it or just dislike it. Now you have to like it or say something negative. It is just adding to this really unfortunate cycle that I think is having an unfortunate effect on women across the world. The online session tackled the question: How can women reach economic and professional parity   The Duchess argued that pushing for paid parity between the sexes was a positive thing both for workers and for companies, while also renewing her calls for paid sick and parental leave in the US. Earlier this month, the Duchess penned an impassioned plea to senior congress members on the topic. In the letter, she argued that a national paid-leave mandate would not only help inidual families, but the country as a whole.  In taking care of your child, you take care of your community, and you take care of your country—because when paid leave is a right, we’re creating a foundation that helps address mental health outcomes, health care costs, and economic strength at the starting line, Meghan wrote. Paid leave should be a national right, rather than a patchwork option limited to those whose employers have policies in place, or those who live in one of the few states where a leave program exists. … This is about putting families above politics. When she was asked about advocating for the change during the summit this evening, Meghan said she was not involving herself in politics as she considered the issue a cross-party, humanitarian one. The Duchess went on to relate the issue of womenaposs rights in the workplace to her own experience as a child. She spoke about how her experience attempting to save and make money when she was younger has taught her lessons that remain with her today, despite her now sizeable wealth. When she admitted being an avid couponer in her younger years, Meghan was asked whether she keeps up the practice today. Do they have coupons anymore, I donapost know. I will never buy something online without finding an online promo code first, the Duchess said, arguing that values learned as a child can stay with a person for le.  If that was engrained with me when I was young, imagine what the world would be likeyou ingrained other elements of financial understanding, especially in young women, so they could move in the world in a dferent way. Meghan went on to tell how she used to make scrunchies out of scraps of fabric to sell as a child. It was that feeling, I had done something myself, she said of the sensation sheaposd get after selling some of her crafts. You get not just purpose, but a sense of self satisfaction. Meghan also expressed her hopes for the future of work post-Covid, arguing for a hybrid model of working from home and in the flesh for those who can.
