title: mum describes horrific moment found
story: Mum describes horric moment she found teenager daughter murdered in Chinese takeawayWenjing Lin, , was murdered by Chun Xu, , at the takeaway in Ynyswen, Rhondda Cynon Taf, she lived in with her mother and stepfather, and her mum has described the heartbreaking moment of finding her bodyWenjing Lin, , was murdered by Chun Xu, , at the takeaway she lived in with her mother and stepfather Image: South Wales Police Athena PicturesByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA mum has described the horric moment she found her daughteraposs body after she was strangled inside a Chinese takeaway. Wenjing Lin, , was murdered by Chun Xu, , at the takeaway in Ynyswen, Rhondda Cynon Taf, where she lived in with her mother, Meang Xu, and stepfather Yongquan Jiang.Xu had admitted manslaughter but denied murder, but was found guilty of the murder of Miss Linn and the attempted murder of Mr Jiang. Ms Xu has described the horrendous moment she found Miss Lin shortly after the killing on March . She told the court: The moment I saw her face had gone black and pale. I went to hug her and her body was cold. I could see her neck was black as she had been strangled.  Speaking outside the court with the support of her husband, Ms Xu said her daughter had passed all her GCSEaposs with As but died before getting the results. She said: My beautul daughter is gone and I can never forgive you. I have lost my beloved daughter, my everything. Everything of me. She cared for my husband and I very much. She has been helping us to communicate with all the English speakers.school friends miss her so much, I know they are suffering from the pain and loss of their best friend. They will never recover from it. Before that horrible day she was a very, very happy girl. She loved spending time with her friends and she enjoyed school.  Weaposve been to the school to speak to them. My daughter has passed all her GCSEaposs with As but she will never know her results that she has worked so hard for. Iaposm so proud of her achievements in the school. She loved school so much and her teachers called her the model student. Iaposm still not able to comprehend why the perpetrator would do this to her. Our lives have been turned upside down. I was crying every day, watching videos every day and trying to feel close to her and listen to her voice. I cannot imagine what my le is like without her. She was my only child. The perpetrator has broken our family. I had to begin counselling to help me but it will never take away the pain the perpetrator has caused us.  Miss Lin was described as an exceptional student by her teacher Rhiannon Davies who had a statement read to the court during the trial. Ms Davies, who taught Wenjingaposs when she was in year  at Treorchy Comprehensive School, said she was hardworking student. Even on the day of her death I was made aware she had logged in for a maths lesson early in the morning, Ms Davies added. She was a fantastic student and is sorely missed. The trial heard how Xu was a heavy gambler and owed the family £,. Michael Jones QC, prosecuting, told the court Xu visited the family armed with a kitchen kne, and an hour before the attacks had Googled can fingerprints be destroyed by fire.  When he was later questioned by a psychologist about his fitness to be questioned by police, he said: I didnapost mean to hurt the little girl. I wanted revenge on her mother. She upset me on many times and didnapost listen to what I say. Xu, also known as Little Gang, was regarded as a nephew to the mother, Ms Xu, as their parents had lived next door to each other in China, but they were not blood relations, Mr Jones said. In December , the family entrusted Xu with £, that he said he would send back to China for them to pay a friend who had loaned them money to start their business in the UK. However, Xu only sent some of the money back and gambled away £,, which he had then begun paying back. On March , , he rang Ms Xu and askedhe could come to see them, but told her not to tell anyone about his visit. That night they ate food together and everyone went to bed. The next morning, Mr Jones said, he strangled to death -year-old Wenjing. An hour before the attack he is said to have Googled dferent iations of whether finger prints on kne will still existburnt by fire. After killing Wenjing, Xu is said to have lured her stepfather, Mr Jiang, into the basement by asking whether he could have a piece of fish from the freezer. In the basement, Xu began attacking Mr Jiang with two knives, stabbing him in the neck and body.  When Mr Jiang asked Xu why he was attacking him, Xu replied: Money, money, money. Ms Xu then came down the basement stairs and saw the two fighting. She tried to ring a friend, and Xu bit her. Mr Jiang fought Xu off and went upstairs to find his stepdaughter, Wenjing. He discovered her lying on her back by the takeaway counter. Despite attempts by the family and then paramedics to resuscitate the teenager, she was pronounced dead at the scene at .pm. Police found Xu in the kitchen, having cut his own throat. He was treated at University Hospital of Wales before being arrested on suspicion of murder and attempted murder. Xu admitted attacking -year-old Mr Jiang, but denied intending to kill him or cause him serious harm. He will be sentenced on Friday at the same court. title: mum flees home after nightmare
story: Mum flees home after nightmare teenage gang threatens to rape her and her kidsA mum-of-three in her s described the shocking moment a gang of youngsters threatened to rape her and her kids, aged five, two and, one - it left her no other option but to flee her Hull homeA Hull gang that forced the fire service to retreat under a barrage of missiles threatened a mum with raping her and her kids Image: MEN MEDIAByHannah Lucas:,  Nov  A terried young mum was forced to flee her home and find shelter in a hotel after a gang threatened to rape her and her children.The mum-of-three says the group of youths have been making it a nightmare for the estate for months, but their campaign has intensied over the past few weeks. She described how on Sunday night her partner was verbally abused by the group on Boothferry estate, in Hull, as he chased them in a bid to recover the bin theyaposd snatched.It was then that the mob threatened to rape me and my kids, the woman, in her s, told HullLive.The terrying threats left the mum no other choice but to flee with her kids aged five, two and one, to the Village Hotel in Henry Boot Way at roughly .pm. Do you live on a nightmare estate  Email webnews@mirror and let us know  The estate has been plagued by anti-social behaviour in and around the Gower Road area for several months. But it has gotten worse in recent weeks, with fire crews forced to retreat under a barrage of missiles and police patrols stepped up. Itaposs been a nightmare for months, but the worst was Sunday night, the mum said. My partner chased them and got our bins back, but then groups just swarmed. They were hurling abuse saying theyaposre going to rape me and my kids, then they were throwing things while I was in the house. Theyaposve been setting bus shelters on fire and aiming fireworks at young school children who are between five and -years-old. My eldest is terried, she has a disability and doesnapost want to be in the house. The mum said le is becoming hell for the estateaposs law-abiding residents as youths torch their bins, launch fireworks at people and hurl abuse.  The woman claims the youths responsible shouted: The police are scared of us, they wonapost do anything. When you try to say something, it just makes it worse and they keep coming back, no ones willing to do anything, she said. When I turned back up at the house this morning because I had to take my eldest to school, metal canisters of nitrous oxide that theyaposd launched were still in the garden. Theyaposre still there now. Humberside Police confirmed they are already looking into multiple cases of arson and anti-social behaviour in and around Boothferry Playing Fields after a bus stop was set alight on Halloween. Meanwhile, Humberside Fire and Rescue crews were also forced to withdraw from Gower Road Park on Sunday, November , after missiles were launched at crew members while they tackled a blaze. Following the torching of the bus shelter, a spokesperson for Humberside Police said: We are investigating a number of incidents of arson and anti-social behaviour in and around Boothferry Playing Fields of Gower Road in Hull. We received reports from the fire service and local residents about a group of young people causing damage and fires in the playing fields and a bus shelter was set alight. This type of antisocial behaviour will not be tolerated and action will be taken against those found to be responsible. There are increased patrols in these areas to try and catch and identy those responsible and to provide reassurance to our communities. title: mum three left no roof
story: Mum-of-three left with no roof at council flat and forced to pee in bucket for weeksThe woman, living in Erith, south east London, said her council-owned flat was in a state of disrepair and her family lived in the cold, with her children crying all the timeA woman hit out at the inhumane conditions at her home after she was left without a roof for three weeks Image: My London BPM MediaByKiro EvansChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov | commentsA mum said she was left with no roof and was forced to pee in a bucket due to construction work at her council flat. The woman, living in Erith, south east London, with her three children, said her family was living in inhumane conditions. She criticised Bexley Council after urgent building work to fix the chimney stack in her home meant scaffolding was used to replace the roof in September. The repairs also affected the plumbing system in the property, so the family had to use a bucket instead of the toilet.The mum also claimed the property was infested with mice, My London reports.Do you have a nightmare housing story  Email webnews@mirror  She said her family felt cold and her children were always in tears, but she refused an alternative offer of a hostel because of safety fears. Pictures of the home show scaffolding and plastic sheets were used in place of the removed roof. The work had to be carried out urgently after surveyors discovered a structural issue caused by dry rot. She told the Local Democracy Reporting Service: The flat was in a state of disrepair and there was no end of problems. My youngest daughter used to just cry. She really didnapost like it. It was not liveable. Everything was water damaged. Itaposs an absolute state. The wind was just blowing through, they didnapost secure the plastic, so it was completely open. She added: This was a multi-agency failure. And the fact that in this day children could be treated in this way is actually disgusting. The fact that my children had to go through what they went through is horrendous. Her three children, all aged eight and under, have since spent time with relatives outside the capital, but she says the ordeal has disrupted their schooling and affected their behaviour. She has since moved after opposition councillors stepped in, but said the issue left her unable to explain to her children why their home was so bad. The mum said: To be honest, I thought aposhow has it come to this apos My kids were crying and I had no answers for them. I canapost even give them their basic needs in le and itaposs an absolutely horrendous feeling. And going to the toilet in a bucket was just inhumane. She is set toto the property later this month once repairs are finished. Labour councillor Nicola Taylor, who became directly involved in the case after Mary visited her constituency office, said: I was shocked when I saw the state of this property and knew we had to get the family to a place of safety immediately. As I have become more involved in this case, I have serious concerns over the quality of these properties andthey are fit for our residents. I have still been unable to obtain surveyor or maintenance reports so I wondercouncil taxpayersapos money is being spent appropriately. Bexley Council said in a statement sent to The Mirror: The welfare of people we place in temporary accommodation is a priority for us and we work hard to ensure their safety. The extent of the repairs to this property only became evident following a leak, inspection by our staff and after a ceiling was removed. We identied the work that would be needed and offered the family alternative accommodation while it was carried out. They have a right to their privacy and we are not prepared to publicly share further details of their case. title: new mum 46 diagnosed incurable
story: New mum, , diagnosed with incurable cancer  weeks after giving birth to baby girlAndrea Kevill-Davies pain was first thought to be kidney stones but the shadows on her bladder turned out to be tumours - her family and friends have now rallied round to support herAndrea Kevill-Davies and her eldest son Connor as she has been diagnosed with cancerByEden LewisAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA new mum was diagnosed with incurable cancer six weeks after giving birth. Andrea Kevill-Daviesapos ongoing pain was first thought to be kidney stones and treatment was deemed too dangerous while she was carrying daughter Daisy. Heartbreakingly, the shadows on the mumaposs bladder turned out to be tumours. Diane Spooner, the -year-oldaposs sister-in-law, said the diagnosis was devastating.The -year-old told TeesideLive : The decision was made to deliver her baby as quickly as possible so she could have a biopsy.Daisy was born on September  this year and Andrea underwent a biopsy just after Daisy was born with Down Syndrome.  As a childminder Andrea knew exactly how to care for her new daughter as she had past experience with children sheaposd looked after. The news also came a week after Andrea buried her father-in-lawA GoFundMe has been created by her friends to help raise money for the family.Diane added: Andrea Whatsapped me last Wednesday saying it wasnapost good news and she was finding out more. She messaged half an hour later saying she had incurable cancer and was starting chemotherapy immediately. Itaposs just devastating, we only buried my father-in-law the week before and now this. Sheaposs had to pack in her job as a childminder whilst she has her treatment and I hope to care for her as much as I did when I was caring for my father-in-law. Andreaaposs eldest son Connor was stationed in Cyprus in the army and has now left so he can help with his Mam and the family.for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email . Despite how heartbreaking it is, the support from the community has been breathtaking as they help raise some funds for Andrea and her family. Sheaposs the loveliest person in the world, sheaposs absolutely amazing and I hope this money can help her create some memories with her family. title: our marriage open because danny
story: Exclusive: Our marriage is open because Danny Dyers right - its cruel to have sex with  personPolyamorous husband and we Paulina and Daniel Tenner say comments made by Eastenders actor Danny Dyer about having sex with the same person forever is cruel really resonateOpen marriage couple Paulina and Daniel Tenner at home in Hoxton Image: TIM ANDERSONByClaire OBoyle:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments Maybe it’s what a lot of married people think and never say. But EastEnders star Danny Dyer - being Danny Dyer - said it aloud last week. He reckons it’s cruel to have sex with just one person forever. So the hardman actor, who is married to his childhood sweetheart Jo Mas, will be green with envy at the lestyle of husband and we Paulina and Daniel Tenner. They’ve been married for eight years... and almost four years ago decided to “open” their marriage and have sex with other people. “If someone had asked me about this a few years back I’d never have thought I’d do it,” says Paulina, . “But that all changed as a result of some workshops I did about relationships, and I realised my sexual le force was blossoming.” It was then the entrepreneur and husband Daniel, , started talking about how an open marriage might work for them.What is your view on open marriages  Have your say in the comment section “For years we’d been monogamous,” says Paulina, who lives with Daniel in London. “But suddenly I was feeling attracted to dferent men, dferent women, everyone. In the early days of discussions, I may have been the driving force for this, but Daniel definitely needed to be on board - and he was. I wouldn’t have done it without us both feeling the same way.” After long discussions with her husband, Paulina started off at parties with other women that allowed her to “explore her bi-curious fantasies” while Daniel also started seeing other women. He says: “We had talked a lot before we made our decision, and we’d come to the same conclusion. Part of the purpose of le is to really feel that you’re alive and to explore all the interesting things in the world. One of the most fascinating things is the relationships we have with other people. To cut off any of these avenues means you’re sacricing an important part of your le, a part you could derive a huge amount of joy from. “That’s why the comments from Danny Dyer really resonate, because you’re cutting things off, you’re cutting off amazing things that you might have discovered through a connectionyou don’t explore it.”  Over two years the couple each had a series of lovers. Paulina connected with both men and women, and Daniel just dated women. Paulina thinks she had around  partners, while Daniel says he’s not interested in keeping count. “To me, counting lovers is a feature of monogamous le, when there’s pressure, especially on men, to have this sort of ego boost from having a large number of lovers,” he says. “It isn’t something I’m interested in.” The pair spent one New Year’s Eve together with their separate partners - Paulina with her Norwegian boyfriend, while Daniel came along with the British woman he was seeing at the time. “We felt like a big, polyamorous family,” says Paulina. “It was so natural and normal. I was with my lover, and Daniel was with the woman he was seeing at the time, a lady I was good friends with. It was lovely, flowing and natural.”  On seeing her husband with another partner Paulina says: “There was no jealousy. In fact there was satisfaction that he was experiencing something new and interesting. We have no secrets and our relationship is wonderfully transparent.” Daniel agrees jealousy is not a factor. “The idea Paulina is have a wonderful experience with someone  does not create jealousy,” he says. “Jealousy is a term that lumps together a bunch of other things, usually the fear of losing the other person and an envy of what they’ve got. But I haven’t felt a fear of losing Paulina to her other lovers, and I was being nourished and getting what I wanted too, so envy didn’t arise either.” Paulina, who has written a book after training in burlesque dancing, Laid Bare: What the Business Leader Learnt From the Stripper, says she built some deep connections with other partners, particularly the Norwegian man she dated for around two years in parallel with her marriage. She says while maintaining more than one relationship at a time might sound like a lot of effort, the newness of having dferent partners is “exciting”. “I actually think online dating sounds way more exhausting,” she laughs. “Just sex with no emotions is not very interesting to me,” adds Paulina. “Of course I get that people want to want to have just have sex, and that’s fine, but for Daniel and I, we’re looking for more depth. OK, it won’t be as deep a connection as we have with each other, but it needs to be more than just friends with benefits. There has to be a real connection for the sex to be worth it.”  Daniel says having other lovers actually brought him closer to his we. “Encounters with other people have been enjoyable,” he says. “But they also made me realise, even as the connections grew deeper with some women, they led me back to my we.” And while the couple enjoyed their two years in an open relationship, just before the lockdown was announced in early  they decided to suspend the open nature of their marriage - although at the minute they are considering opening it up once again. Pauline says: “At the minute we’re just together but it’s something we might come back to as it gave us so much joy and pleasure, as long as we protect the space for ourselves too.” Daniel adds: “I might be a step further towards opening up again than Paulina is. I don’t want to get to the end of my le and think I had all these opportunities to explore connections and didn’t take them.” The couple, who have been attending couples therapy for more than a year, are considering having children in the future. They have not yet decidedthey would follow the open marriage model while having a family, although Daniel thinks this would offer an open-minded and healthy example to any children. Paulina adds: “We think so many people would be happierthey knew polyamory was a valid option for them. We think there would be less cheating and fewer hearts would be brokenother couples were open about wanting about to make other connections in their le and decided to follow those connections with openness and honesty.”Laid Bare: What The Business Leader Learnt From the Stripper, by Paulina Tenner is out on November . title: pent up frustration came pouring
story: Pent-up frustration came pouring out as Brits entered US following Covid travel banHours early, and on board BA’s flight, there was a chorus of applause as it, and Virgin Atlantic’s jet took to the skies together in a first for two commercial servicesA party atmosphere greeted those arriving in New York from BritainopinionByGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  Nov | commentsA party atmosphere greeted those arriving in New York from Britain yesterday - with the Daily Mirror among the very first passengers to step through the doors.But the colourful balloons and cheers could not disguise the seriousness of what had come before during  long months of separation for so many families.For during that time there have been missed birthdays, Christmas get-togethers, weddings and, sadly, funerals. Hours early, and on board BA’s flight, there was a chorus of applause as it, and Virgin Atlantic’s jet took to the skies together in a first for two commercial services.You could also hear the palpable sigh of relief from the airline bigwigs present that this moment had arrived, and with it their hope will make a fightback from what has driven other competitors to the wall.  It is also important for those businesses that can finally meet others face-to-face. And it is a big day for tourism chiefs in the Big Apple banking on aof the big spending British shoppers. But yesterday was never really about the firms involved, it was about the iniduals on board - and those who have rushed to book flights - counting down the hours, the day the weeks until they can embrace precious loved ones again. Any video call will never, ever, make up for the emotions witnessed at JFK’s arrivals hall yesterday, when  months or more of pent-up sadness, frustration and finally relief came pouring out. title: professions covid vaccine full list
story: Which professions have to have the Covid vaccine  Full list and exemptionsThe government is set to make Covid vaccines mandatory for all frontline workers. Here’s everything we need to know including the full list of professions considered as frontline staffThe health minister believes that making jabs mandatory will drive up vaccination rates Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByMalvika Padin:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments All frontline NHS staff and social care workers in England will be required to get both doses of the Covid- vaccines from April  next year.Health Secretary Sajid Javid has announced the move to make vaccines mandatory for frontline workers, with those of the , frontline personnel who have not yet had both doses of Covid vaccine will have to get jabbed or face dismissal.Previously, Justice Secretary and Deputy Prime Minister Dominic Raab refused to comment on the reports, but told BBC Breakfast that the government has been “very mindful of encouraging greater take-up – or maximum take-upyou like – of the vaccination and the boosters,” particularly in vulnerable settings like care homes and NHS.  NHS Providers chief executive Chris Hopson told BBC Radio  thatdone right, the decision could drive take-up of the vaccines up .Here’s who be will impacted by the move to make vaccines mandatory. Who will the mandatory vaccination rule apply to  Frontline staff usually means staff that work directly with the public, rather than behind closed doors or in a support capacity.  This would include:doctors nurses midwives paramedics pharmacists social workers and care workersThe only people exempt from the mandatory policy will be those who do not have to face contact with patients and those who have a medical exemption. How many NHS workers do not have the jab  While care groups have been calling for the mandatory vaccine policy to be axed or delayed so providers can get through winter challenges without more staff leaving, the rule that they have to be immunised by this Friday or risk losing their job has seen many care workers who initially refused the vaccine, take the immunisation.  The health minister believes that, while some NHS staff may leave, making jabs mandatory will drive up vaccination rates by prompting those who have been refusing to finally get vaccinated in the same way that has already occurred with care home staff. According to latest NHS figures, almost a quarter of the care home staff were not recorded as having been double jabbed as of October , which means they might lose their jobs this week. Three-quarters of staff working in other social care settings outside of care homes, including non-registered providers and those employed by local authorities, have had their first jab. But only a third of them were doubled jabbed, with many having self-certied as exempt or applied for official proof. title: walkers confirms cause crisp shortage
story: Walkers confirms cause of crisp shortage – and fans are not happyIconic in both flavour and appearance, Walkers crisps are a staple of the British shop shelf and the British diet, but in a crisis being dubbed by some as the worst this year, lovers have been left very unhappyWalkers crisps are a familiar sight on the UKs shelves... in happier times Image: Getty ImagesByHarry Thompson:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments Is there a more familiar sight on the shelves of the UKaposs supermarkets and corner shops than the bold block colours of Walkers crisp packets, neatly lined up and assorted in enticing technicolour  But in recent weeks this has seemed like a distant memory, with the shelves usually dedicated to Britainaposs most iconic crisp brand looking thin and depleted.The shortage has led the company to produce an apology explaining the cause of the crisis – an IT system failure. The company, who are based in Leicester, has said that the shortage could last to the end of the month with current stock already in short supply. It is understood the midlands factory is producing fewer packets than usual due to the glitch.  A spokesperson for the potato packaging powerhouse said: A recent IT system upgrade has disrupted the supply of some of our products. Our sites are still making crisps and snacks, but at a reduced scale. Weaposre doing everything we can to increase production and get peopleaposs favourites back on shelves. Weaposre very sorry for the inconvenience caused. It is understood the problem has been fixed, but the issue has caused hindered the productiveness of its factories.In  data collectors Statistia reported that Walkers enjoyed a huge share of the UKaposs crisp output, with a total sales volume that year of  million kilograms. In second place were own label brands at just  million kilograms, McCoys in third with  and Kettles in fourth with ..Founded in Leicester in  by Henry Walker, it was bought  years later in  by Frito-Lay, a ision of PepsiCo who have just completed a £ million upgrade to the firmaposs distribution centre in Beaumont Leys, a suburb in northwest Leicester.  In October  Gary Lineker signed a new contract worth £. million with the savoury snack giants, ensuring their union until .Given the history, market share and financial resources of the firm, it is understandable that people have taken to Twitter to express their panic, with some arguing itaposs the most signicant crisis to confront he nation this year.We’ve not had walkers crisps in our Tescos for weeks. Disaster, said one struggling user. I can tolerate no bog roll, petrol and all the other nonsense but a shortage of Walkers crisps is too much for me, said another.The Walkers crisp are the latest in a long line of goods that have been hit by supply chain disruption, which have beleaguered the UKaposs economic response to Covid- causing chaos in the UKaposs stores. The issues are related to Brexit and Covid, which have led to staff shortages. The haulage industry has been particularly heavily hit, reportedly being left , drivers short.Comment MORE ON Gary LinekerTescoFrito Lay Inc." data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: wetherspoons lover claims served super
story: Wetherspoons lover claims he was served super-sized chip measuring . inchesHarry Tayler has been forced to defend his discovery, after angered fries fanatics questioned how the chip could have been sliced from a single spudHarry Tayler couldnt help filming his potato chip before he tucked into his meal Image: Kennedy News and MediaByAdam Wareing:,  Nov | comments AWetherspoonsfan has claimed he was served “the biggest chip ever seen” at one of his beloved pubs, insisting the spud fry stretched a massive . inches. Harry Tayler filmed his super-sized chip as he and his pal Connor Armento, tucked into a wrap and burger at The Old Swanne Inne in Evesham,Worcestershire , on Friday afternoon.The -year-old has been forced to defend his discovery, after angered fries fanatics questioned how the chip could have been sliced from a single spud. Others went as far as to claim heaposd bitten a chipaposs ends off and joined two others on either side.AFacebookpost from Harry following the discovery sees the college student pan his camera across the fullof the aposbeastapos, before his smirking companion looks down the lens to declare apositaposs the biggest chip Iaposve ever seenapos.Stunned fans rushed to the comments to congratulate -year-old college student Harry on his aposmonsterapos find, with more than  people reacting to his bemusing announcement. Harry hit back at demands he aposshould be ashamedapos of the alleged scam by angrily replying “of course itaposs real, grow up”. He went on to shut down another sceptic, saying: “ you can’t accept the fact my chipaposs bigger than yours, please leave”. Harryaposs since boasted he even showed shocked aposSpoons staff the discovery. He felt guilty eating it, so left it until last - but said the super-sized chip did taste good in the end. Harry said he hadn’t even noticed the giant chip until a few minutes after he started eating, at which point he thought apositaposs bl**dy massiveapos. We were both shocked at the time, as you can tell by Connor in the video,” he said. “We measured it on an app he had on his phone. It was quite funny.  Some people didnapost believe it and others did. Harryaposs post said: Wetherspoons Evesham. Old Swan Inn. The sheer size of this beast. . inches. Dan Tustin said: That is one big chip, congrats on the find. Cameron Sherry questioned: How can that have been birthed from a single spud  Kenny Benet said: I am not buying it. You just bit the ends off the middle chip and shoved one in either side! Jimmy Seay agreed and added: Multiple chips inserted into one another, itaposs plain to see. Another Facebook user, Dan Evans, said he wasn’t buying the story and went on to say Harry should “be ashamed”.Scott Russell simply added: Photoshopped.Last month,Sam Mumfordhit the headlines after finding what he claimed to be aposthe worldaposs longest chipapos stretching a giant . inches, but was also hit by claims that he was holding two chips together.Comment MORE ON Dan EvansAppsEducationSchoolsFood" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: whatsapp groups set major change
story: WhatsApp set for major change with app update transforming Groups According to insider reports, the change to the messaging  will let you create groups inside of other GroupsSome WhatApp features never make it past testingthey don’t work as intended Image: REUTERSByMirror:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsWhatsapp has a change in store which will change how its Groupsworks. According to insider reports, the change to the messaging  will let you create groups inside of other Groups. With this change, WhatsApp would come to be more like rival messengers Slack, the messaging  used primarily for work, and Discord, which is used for gaming. The newcould be useful to those with work communities that are segmented into lots of smaller groups within. Alternatively, community messenger groups could utilise theby splitting the group into separate chats for schooling or complaints about litter.According to reports from the Sun Online, clues about the new feature were first revealed in October, by tech site XDA Developers. And WhatsApp sleuths atWABetaInfohave now uncovered a preview showcasing what the feature would mean for users. While the preview gives a hint into what is to come, it doesn’t make it clear exactly what the feature will do. This name could mean anything, WABetaInfo said. But a Community is a new place where Group admins have more control over Groups on WhatsApp. Mainly to group other Groups easily. It’s likely the feature will be tested in the beta version of WhatsApp first, but it could take weeks or months, or even years for the feature to roll out to the general public. XDA Developers have warned that waiting for this feature could be a timely exercise. With the speed of feature introduction on WhatsApp, it could also take years before this feature comes to a stable release, the group previously said. On the flipside, some WhatApp features never make it past testingthey don’t work as intended. WhatsApp is also thought to be testing a feature that lets you use the app on multiple devices.WhatsApp haslost a lot of usersover the last year due to ongoing privacy concerns around its new terms of service.WhatsApp has traditionally marketed itself on offering secure, encrypted messaging, but announced wildly unpopular changes to the way it handles user data. These changes would have seen user data handed to private companies to aid in marketing. WhatsApp U-turned drastically on the plans following a major backlash which has seen competitors Telegram surpass one billion downloads. These changes would have seen user data handed to private companies to aid in marketing. It seems big tech companies are closing in on anyone who doesnapost want to buy the latest kit every year.Googleannounced that it plans to completely end sign-in support for older Android devices this month. title: youre not friend you use
story: "Youre not a friendyou use racist language - Gary Ballance should know that"Ex-England cricketer Gary Ballance said that he called Yorkshire county teammate, Azeem Rafiq, a “P***” – but said it was done “in the spirit of friendly banter”Gary Ballance admitted calling Azeem Rafiq a p*** Image: Getty ImagesopinionByDarren Lewis:,  Nov | commentsMost of us Black or Asian people you know will have one. The “friend” who thinks knowing us insulates them from the charge of racism when they are being just that. Ex-England cricketer Gary Ballance admitted in a statement last week he’d called Yorkshire teammate, Azeem Rafiq, a “P***” – but said it was done “in the spirit of friendly banter” . Ballance has come clean because, in August , Rafiq gave an interview in which he spoke about the racism he experienced at Yorkshire, including an “openly racist” captain and a dressing room in which racist comments were seen as humorous. The club effectively stuck its head in the sand, but an independent report has blown the whole thing wide open. Sponsors have withdrawn their cash, chairman Roger Hutton has resigned and English cricket’s most successful county has been banned from hosting internationals.  But back to Ballance. He claims to be incredulous that calling an Asian person the P-word could cause the kind of hurt and anguish it did to Rafiq. “If I’d believed it, I would have stopped immediately,” said Ballance. “He was my best cricket mate and I cared deeply for him.” Just not enough to stop using this horrendous racist slur against him. It is easy to believe this is a story just about Yorkshire, cricket or even sport. It isn’t. Go into any office, factory, shop floor or football club you like and you’ll find at least one dinosaur convinced that racist abuse can be used as a term of affection. ‘Can a racist term ever be defined as banter ’ trilled the Twitter account of the BBC’s Question Time. Yes, really. It may as well have asked whether slapping your partner is ever justied. Or whether political corruption is ever justiedthe money is for a good cause.  If ever we needed a snapshot of the institutional racism that infects this country to its core, the past week has provided it. Ironically, there is more outrage and anger directed at those who call it out - as Rafiq has found to his cost - than at the issue itself. Yet the fact remains, across any number of industries and sports, iniduals like him iniably find themselves one of the only Black or Asian people in the room at the mercy of the bigots. Across the country you’ll find iniduals pulling the emergency ripcord defence that their workmate, best friend, neighbour, partner, even husband or we is black. Asthat allows them a free pass to use the kind of language or go down the routes that would otherwise see them vilied. The Government does it even now. Prime Minister Boris Johnson surrounds himself with gatekeepers such as Kwasi Kwarteng, Kemi Badenoch and Priti Patel, believing it protects him from stick for describing Burqa-wearing women as looking like letterboxes. Or describing black people as ‘picaninnies’. Question Time is no exception. Presumably pointing to whatever black or Asian members it has on its production team. And no, it is no defence that the offensive question tweeted was one posed by an audience member to spark debate. Rafiq’s forthcoming appearance in front of a parliamentary select committee may well bring the rest of Yorkshire’s house of cards down. But the shock waves are already reverberating way beyond cricket. PS: You’re not someone’s friendyou’re using racist language towards them. news us-news brits-who-waited--months-"New York: Long queues form at JFK after restrictions easedByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsHundreds of passengers were left waiting for hours at JFK airport in New York yesterday when three planes from the UK arrived at the same time. The US border re-opened to British travellers for the first time in  days or nearly  months. One traveller took to social media to share a video of long lines and blasting officials for disgraceful planning. It showed long queues snaking around the arrivals hall as hundreds wait to be let into the US. America is expecting a flood of international visitors crossing its borders by air and by land on Monday after lting travel restrictions for much of the worldaposs population first imposed in early  to address the spread of Covid-.  More than , passengers flew from London to New York City yesterday. British Airways took , travellers on  planes while Virgin Atlantic brought a further , customers on  flights shuttles into JFK.One Twitter user shared a video of the backlog of traffic and blamed three planes landing at once.He wrote:  months closed lots of time to get things right and JFK Airport queues are a disgrace, three planes landing at the same time from Manchester is ridiculous.  Asked how long he had been waiting, he added: Two hours mate, pathetic. We were all sweating. Just approaching Manhattan now. Paul Richards, , who is head of safeguarding for Stoke City FC, also said he waited two hours after his Virgin Atlantic flight from London.He told USA Today : No point in getting irate, the queue will still be there. Policeman Marc Evans, , who flew from Manchester, with his we and two children said he waited more than an hour. He said: It was apparently a PR stunt to show the USA was back open but seems they werenapost concerned about the queues at customs. Another wrote on Twitter: Great. Queues are JFK are bad enough without two planes touching down at the same time. Delta Air Lines Chief Executive Ed Bastian had earlier said: Itaposs going to be a bit sloppy at first. I can assure you, there will be lines, unfortunately. He added: Weaposll get it sorted out. Heathrow Airport also received numerous complaints on social media for long queues. One wrote on Twitter: Beside myself with appalling service of @BritishAirwaysT trying to get my lovely mum on a flight! @HeathrowAirport waiting  hours now! for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.She added: Sheaposs gone through security. But we are both in tears… this is not a good experience! Another wrote: @HeathrowAirport someone needs to inform your airport assistance personnel that a long connection is nice license to leave a customer sitting and waiting. Yesterday was an emotional day for many as Britons were reunited with friends and family for the first time in  months. Heartwarming images showed couples and families embracing for the first time in nearly two years. Currently, Brits need to be fully vaccinated against Covidthey want to visit the US for non-essential reasons, such as a holiday. Youaposll need to be able to show proof of full vaccination such as the AstraZeneca, BIBP Sinopharm, Covishield, Janssen, Moderna, Pfizer-BioNTech and Sinovac vaccines. Youaposll also need to show proof of a negative Covid PCR test result taken within  hours before departure, and face masks are mandatory in planes travelling into within out of the USA, as well as airports. Children under  are exempt from the vaccine requirements, but they will need to take a test within - days of arrival .Travel rules are correct at the time of writing but can change quickly during the pandemic, so before planning a trip make sure to always check the Foreign Officeaposs latest USA travel advice. You can also get more information on the US government website.If youaposre not fully vaccinated against Covid, youaposll need an essential reason to travel to the USA. If you meet the criteria, youaposll need to self-isolate for your first seven days after arrival, and also take a test within - days of arrival. news us-news fertility-clinic-mix-up-leads-"Tearful couple devastated after fertility clinic mix upByChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA couple who gave birth to someone aposs baby after an alleged mix-up at a fertility clinic said they were devastated to discover the child they had been raising was not theirs. Daphna Cardinale, , and her husband Alexander said they could not experience the first months of le of their second daughter, who was born in another family after embryos were exchanged. The mum explained: Alexander and I are devastated, we missed an entire year of our daughteraposs le. I didnapost get to experience being pregnant with her, or birthing her. We missed her entire newborn period, we never saw our babyaposs entrance into the world or cuddled her in her first seconds of le. Our memories of childbirth will always be tainted by the sick reality that our biological child was given to someone . And the baby with I fought to bring into this world was not mine to keep. The dad added: When the truth came to light, it made exchanging the children all the more heartbreaking. Losing the birth child that you now for the genetic child that you donapost even know yet. Itaposs a truly impossible nightmare that inflicted trauma.Mrs and Mr Cardinale welcomed a little girl in September  and became immediately suspicious because the baby had a darker skin tone than theirs. Initially, they put their thoughts aside as they trusted the IVF process and started raising the child as they fell in love with her. However, two months after the birth, they decided to carry out at-home DNA tests, making the shocking discovery that the girl was not their biological daughter and they had been raising someone aposs child. The tests also meant that another couple had been raising the Cardinalesapos biological child, according to a lawsuit filed on Monday. Together with the couple who had been affected by the mix-up, the parents decided to swap the girls and start raising their own babies - after missing out on their births and first months of le. This week, they announced their decision to sue the IVF clinic where the alleged mix-up happened. Mrs Cardinale said her familyaposs heartbreak and confusion canapost be understated, adding she was robbed of the ability to carry my own child.The lawsuit explains that the couple sought help from the Calornia Center for Reproductive Healthand In VitroTech Labs, an embryology lab, in the summer of .In VitroTech Labs allegedly inserted the embryos into the wrong women.  The legal document reads: Daphna was surgically implanted - against her will or knowledge - with the sperm and egg of a man and woman who were complete strangers to her. Meanwhile, Daphna and Alexander’s embryo was transferred to that same couple, Couple Two, a few weeks after Daphna’s transfer procedure. Couple Two carried to term and gave birth to a baby girl - Alexander and Daphna’s biological child - and raised her for months before Defendants’ mistakes were uncovered and proven. The lawsuit adds that when Mrs Cardinale gave birth to a daughter that was not hers, her husband felt like something was wrong. The document explains: He expected to see a fair child, much like their older daughter. Instead, their Birth Daughter came out with much darker skin and jet-black hair. It was so jarring that Alexander actually took several steps away from the birthing table, backing up against the wall. According to the document, some friends and family members also started questioning the couple about the babyaposs appearance.  The situation led to disconnect between the couple as Mr Cardinale - a musician - was worried his we was in denial. He was so upset that he would stay up at night, staring at their newborn child, wonderingshe was truly theirs, the lawsuit adds. The document says: After learning this, Daphna insisted they take the DNA test, expecting that the results would put everyone’s mind at ease. After several rounds of DNA tests, the Cardinales found out the truth and on December ,  contacted the couple who had been raising their biological child. When they met at a lawyeraposs office, their meeting was terribly uncomfortable, the legal document says. On December , the couples met with their children and for the first time they got to see their biological daughters.  The following day, the Cardinales told their older daughter about the mix-up and she was crushed and terried of losing her birth sister, begging her parents not to switch the babies. About two weeks later, the parents officially switched their children, which took an emotional toll on the whole family. The lawsuit states: The horror of this situation cannot be understated. Mrs Cardinale, who works as a therapist, and her singer-songwriter husband have had to seek help for symptoms of anxiety, depression, and PTSD, the legal action explains. Adam B Wolf, a lawyer representing the Cardinales, said the second family also plans to sue the IVF clinic but wants to remain anonymous. In vitro fertilisationis one of several techniques available to help people with fertility problems have a baby.During IVF, an egg is removed from the womanaposs oies and fertilised with sperm in a laboratory, the NHS explains.The fertilised egg, called an embryo, is then ed to the womanaposs womb to grow and develop. It can be carried out using your eggs and your partneraposs sperm, or eggs and sperm from donors. The Mirror has contacted CCRH and In VitroTech Labs for comment. title: family stunned pet dog turns
story: Family stunned as pet dog turns out to be wild fox that mauled livestockA family believed they had purchased a Siberian husky puppy but later found out it was in fact a fox after it went on a killer rampage in a neighbourhood in PeruMaribel Soleto thought shed bought a dog Image: NewsflashByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Nov | comments A family were stunned after learning their apospet dog apos was actually a wild fox - and had been mauling their ducks and chickens instead of protecting them.Maribel Soleto purchased the dog thinking it was a cute Siberian husky pup, and as it grew she didnapost notice the tell-tale signs that it was actually a fox. She named the dog Run Run, and when local livestock was being attacked at night she never thought that it could be her pet that was the culprit.But then someone pointed out that their dog looked suspiciously like an Andean fox - complete with bushy tail and pointed head, as Sky News reports. Maribel, from Lima, Peru, said: We had thought he was a purebred puppy. A lady told us that it had eaten three large guinea pigs.Walter Silva, a local veterinarian and wildle specialist, said it is not uncommon for wild animals to be brought from Amazonian areas by traffickers to be illegally traded in Lima.He said: Trafficking in wildle brings these consequences. Many specimens are captured from hatchlings. For this, they kill the parents and these juveniles are illegally traded in informal markets. In this case, a fox bought as a domestic dog. The fox has since gone missing, but officials of the state National Forest and Wildle Service said they will take him to a special centre or zoo once he is found. Meanwhile, one dog owner was relieved when she finally discovered why she constantly had aposfilthyapos windows - as she caught her dog mindlessly licking them. Anna Dunford, , has two Siberian huskies, Bear and Baloo, and for the past two years her windows had been growing increasingly hard to keep clean and she had no idea why. Then one day, her mother was looking after the dogs and went to prepare their food in the kitchen, and to de-stress the process she shut the dogs in the next room, separated by a door with glass windows. The hungry dogs lined up to watch as their dog-sitter scooped out their food, and as she glanced back she noticed that eager Baloo had his nose pressed against the glass and was licking away in anticipation. a apos time traveller from apos has shared video footage of a deserted city as proof that heaposs the aposlast person on Earthapos. Javier has become a bit of a hit on TikTok where he uploads videos as @unicosobreviviente, which translates to aposonly survivorapos, but heaposs not without his haters.He claims to be stuck alone in the future as the rest of the earthaposs population has been wiped out by a disaster, and he uploads videos of the Spanish city he is in as proof. But some say that heaposs filming deserted parts or visiting areas at quiet times of day, so the TikToker has now uploaded footage of a busy city junction - which is eerily deserted. What do you think about Javieraposs claims  Let us know in the comments...In the past, Javier has shared footage of a secret passageway in the abandoned city, and clips from a shopping area thataposs become a ghost town - but was recently challenged by a follower on social media. They asked him to upload a clip with a view, which he did, then they asked him to upload the same clip but filmed in the daytime - saying they would believe himthat too made the city look empty. So Javier did so, and in this clip, the roads of the city look completely empty - but TikTok users were still quick to pick the footage part. news weird-news woman-feels-broken-after-discovering-"TikTok user reveals the caller’s identity of mystery voicemailsByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA woman says she feels aposbrokenapos after discovering hundreds of voicemails on her phone, from a blocked number which she didnapost recognise.The TikTok user, who posts from the handle @waoodd.png, was clearing out her voicemails, when she discovered hundreds of messages dating back more than a year, all from the same woman.In the messages, the woman could be heard saying I miss you, and I love you, over and over, as well as crying down the phone. After listening to more of the messages, the -year-old TikToker realised the messages werenapost from a stalker, and they were in fact from a woman who had lost her husband and was leaving messages for her deceased partner on his old number. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Youaposre just trying to clear your voicemails and notice a number you donapost recognise in blocked numbers ... that has been leaving you voicemails since July , , the TikToker wrote alongside a clip of herself crying. All the voicemails consist of aposI miss youapos and and aposI hope youaposre okayapos and long pauses and what sounds to be soft crying  The -year-old then shared a screengrab from her phone, showing all the messages sheaposd been receiving, sometimes having four missed voicemails per day from the grieving lady. She quietly played one of the messages out loud, in which the woman can be heard saying: Itaposs just me, youaposve been on my mind. Iaposll catch you later, bye. The TikTok user continued: Then you realise itaposs this old lady leaving voicemails to her [late] husband... In the comments section, the TikToker asked for advice on whether she should call the lady or just continue allowing her to leave the messages, and she later concluded that she would leave the woman to it, as many suggested it was probably a much-needed coping mechanism for her. Many people also commented to say they have similar coping mechanisms, and regularly leave messages for loved ones who have passed away. Hereaposs to hoping this lady gets the closure she needs.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news world-news mcdonalds-share-prep-employees-before-"McDonalds worker demonstrates how she opens up on first shtByGraeme Murray:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsMcDonaldaposs staff have shown the preparation they have to do before opening, but people are horried by the oil in the frier. The eatery opens at am, but Maura Estafeliz has set up everything an hour before her sht.She first turns on all the machines including the fryer, boilers, heaters, ice cream machines and computers. The employee records the time before filling up the ice cream machine with milk and prepares the drink station. She tells how she fills all the soft drinks before making fresh coffee and tea. Maura then pours a bag of ground coffee into the machine and lets it brew.  Meanwhile, she grabs a bucket of ice to fill up the iced coffee and iced tea machines. She pours the hot coffee into a ice-filled plastic bag to cool down and starts making tea with another tray.. The worker than has to do some computer work where she prints out all the inventory lists and ticks boxes on the menu checklists ensure the restaurant is ready to open. Her tasks continue marking expiry dates for ingredients such as creamer, coffee and eggs.The Daily Star reports that she can then say: All done, after placing printed out labels where they are needed.Some people thought they were watching a complete McDonaldaposs video, but others were horried by the colour of the oil in the fryer and asked when it was last changed. The publication reported one person asking questions about the oil in the frier. The Daily Star reports he said: How is no one talking about the oil there  It looks like itaposs been there since apos. Training completed, when do I start  a second wrote. And a third person added: This is a lot of damn work for a minimum wage. Maura told her viewers she had followed the health and safety procedures evenshe was not filmed wearing gloves. She added: We always change oil on Mondays and theyaposre going to change it tomorrow Weaposre not required to wear gloves just because I didnapost record myself washing my hands and disinfecting things doesnapost mean I didnapost do it. title: model claims instagram keep deleting
story: Model claims Instagram keep deleting account as Im so hot people just think Im fakeVeronika Rajek, a former Miss Slovakia  finalist, travels the world making content for her Instagram – and claims people are "always surprised" when they meet her for the first timeVeronika Rajeka says that le is harder for beautul people Image: Jam Press @veronikarajekByDominique Starbuck:,  Nov | commentsA model has claimed her Instagram keeps getting deleted because too many people believe she isnapost a real person. Veronika Rajekaposs social media profile are regularly reported as being fake, she has claimed. The -year-old believes that aposle is harder for beautul people and that she so hot people just think Iaposm fake. Others allegedly bully the former Miss Slovakia  finalist for having had plastic surgery, which she insists isnapost true. People don’t even believe I exist, Veronika said. It’s pretty discriminatory that other women can do the same thing as me and I can’t, and I just get deleted because of my looks.  I call myself an alien as people don’t believe I’m real. They think I’m an AI robot or a catfish online. People say beautul people have it easy but I have it worse as people make it harder for me because I’m beautul.The model, based in Vienna, Austria, travels the world making content for her Instagram – and claims people are always surprised when they meet her for the first time.Veronika claims she receives hundreds of messages from women body shaming her on a regular basis and that many claim she uses filters to advance her looks.  Veronika, who has . million followers on Instagram, said: I get messages from men who donapost think Iaposm real but the worst messages on my Instagram are from women asking me why I’m pretending and asking for proof. I don’t make any adjustments, shaping or filters – I use a skin smoothing tool but I think that’s normal. Skinny girls are body shaming plus-sized models but I’m being body shamed too as they donapost think I’m natural.  I get more abuse from women as they are jealous and they think I want their boyfriend. Only women can hurt other women so strongly. I donapost think I’m perfect but I’m natural in real le, but people are scared of me and donapost want to talk to me. To end the rumours of plastic surgery and claims sheaposs a catfish or robot, Veronika has resorted to desperate measures. She is planning to get a scan of her breasts to prove people wrong. The model paid £ for a breast examination while in Dubai in October, which included a quick scan. She said: I was forced to do this check-up to get people to believe me. People question the naturality of my breasts so I went to a doctor to get a breast examination and proof that they’re real, with no enhancements, objects or scars. My doctor was really surprised as she thought I’d had surgery too and said I had the most beautul natural breasts.  I worked out so much at teenage years that I developed muscles which make my breasts a nice shape. I’m not trying to be sexual, I just have big boobs. God gave me these gts and I want people to believe me. Veronika takes good care of her body - not drinking or partying, instead working out five times a week. But her beauty has also come at a price. She added: ‘I don’t have many friends but I feel good. If you feel beautul the way you are, then you are beautul. If you feel confident in your body and you are plus-sized, then just be confident. “If you have had plastic surgery, just be honest. If you take care of yourself, you can be beautul too. title: mum twin girls 4 who
story: Mum of twin girls, , who died in house fire says no more mumma in tragic messageSisters Ophelia and Tarrow died when a fire broke out in their bedroom in Byron Bay, New South Wales, Australia, leaving their parents devastatedTwin girls Ophelia and Tarrow pictured with their mother Akira Garton Image: InstagramByDanya BazaraaSenior News Reporter:,  Nov | commentsThe mum of four-year-old twin girls who tragically died in a house fire has listed the heartbreaking things she will no more have. Sisters Ophelia and Tarrow died when a fire broke out in their bedroom in Byron Bay, New South Wales, Australia while they were staying with their dad James Wright. Their mum Akira Garton wrote no more mumma ... no more hands ... no more smiles, no more dancing, no more moments like this in a devastating post online. It is believed a candle placed on a piano was the cause of the fire on Sunday, according to reports. There’s no suggestion of any wrongdoing and no charges have been laid in the accident, reports say.  Ambulance crews attempted CPR on the little girls but devastatingly they were unable to be revived.“Thank you for every thought, word, text, missed call and gesture,” their mother Akira wrote on Tuesday morning,  news reports.“Words cannot express waking up to Day  of these beautul bunnikins not here ... no more mumma ... no more hands ... no more smiles, no more dancing, no more moments like this, happy, so happy - October  . “I’m devastated. It was too early. I never thought I’d use social media to communicate this.  “I will try to respond when I can and have words beyond disbelief.”A gofundme page has been set up to help the grieving mum.The page says: Every mother’s worst nightmare suddenly became reality for our darling Akira on Sunday morningwhen she heard the news that her  year old twin girls had lost their lives in a house fire in Goonengary, NSW, Australia. Tarrow and Ophelia were bright, playful, identical twins that had a sparkle in their eyes and angelic features.  They loved and adored their older sister Maitreya so so much… just as they were loved and adored by all close to them. There is no word in English for a parent who loses their child, and there shouldn’t be. It is an unthinkable tragedy. Akira and her family are shattered to the core they have an unbearable amount of grief to carry and heartbreaking pain to endure. Friends of the twinsapos dad have also set up a fundraiser to help him cover upcoming expenses. The gofundme says: :Early on Sunday morning November the th our dear Jimmi lost his darling girls, Ophelia and Tarrow to a tragic house fire.These beautul little fairies left this earth too soon, and the loss for Jimmi and family is unspeakable. It is now for us, his friends and family, to come together and create a legacy of lasting love and support. Aside from the onslaught of grief and sorrow, that is already devastating the family, there is an impending slew of debt, funeral costs, and day-to-day expenses that we hope to cover through this collection. Comment MORE ON TwinsGrieving" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from The Courier and the Evening .Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access The Courier and the EveningePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to The Courier or the EveningePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on    Monday – Friday, am – pm, or email.Your subscription to The Courier will allow you to access all of the Eveningstories which are now available on The Courier website. All of the best Eveningcontent, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on The Courier website and will be available for you as part of your subscription. If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Courier ePaper.The new website is now live. Eveningcontent can now be found on The Courier website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing EveningWeb subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Courier website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Courier website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The Courier website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. title: egg producers call for flexible pricing as costs rise
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. title: aberdeen angus society in turmoil as president resigns
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
