story: The SNP government#s refusal to heed recommendations from CalMac on how many new ferries the operator required to service its routes has led directly to the crisis that has overtaken Scotland#s ferry service.No fewer than  of CalMac#s  active vessels are now more than  years old, which is the recommended operational lespan of a ferry.A debate on the on-going ferry crisis took place this week at the Scottish Parliament.It was very telling that those SNP members who took part in the debate were quite unable, or unwilling, to launch a defence of their own government#s record when it comes to the crisis affecting our ferry service.They know, as we all do, that SNP ministers have failed in their duty of care to our island communities and that excuses will no longer cut it.Nicola Sturgeon now needs to admit her government#s -year failure to protect our leline ferry service, and then actually do something about it, and quickly.I am appealing for used postage stamps which help me raise funds which I then donate to the Guide Dogs for the Blind.Recycling used postage stamps is such an easy way to raise money for the charity and I am always in need of all types of postage stamps, including British, foreign and Christmas stamps.If you are able to help I would be gratefulyou could cut the stamps from their envelopes, leaving approximately cm margin around the stamp, and send them to: Myrna Chave, PO Box , Virginia Water, Surrey, GU ARThank you to everyone who has donated in the past, your assistance in helping me to support this very worthy cause is greatly appreciated.My email address is stampsgdftb@live for more information.

title: photograph of the week november 5 2021
story: #We were looking at the standing stones when a wee treecreeper flew in under the roof, saw us, panicked and turned left straight into a wall and knocked himself out for a wee minute,# Kevin said.#We picked him up and checked him over and kept him safe until he was right as rain again.#We managed to get some beautul pictures of the little fellow. The birds are very well camouflaged in the trees so can be a rare find to see close up.#If you have a photograph you would like to share, please email it to editor@campbeltowncourier or send it via the Courier#s Facebook page.

title: thought for the week november 5 2021
story: There are two kinds of silence.There is the kind that numbs and kills, the kind Simon and Garfunkel sang about.It is the silence imposed upon people – that refuses to hear the cry of the hurt, the wounded, the lonely, the unemployed, the hungry, the vulnerable.Veteransfrom wars, and the daily papers strike glorious attitudes. Suffering from unspeakable trauma, they retreat into silence.Breadwinners lose their jobs, and are condemned to poverty, loss of home, reliance on food banks, endless indignity.Young people struggle with mental illness earth and sea, animal and insect le, struggle beneath the load of pollution – and are met with silence.That silence, the silence of the neon god, breeds lies – lies that threaten our planet, our lives and our souls.But there is a dferent kind of silence: a kindly, warm, nurturing silence.It is the silence of the rich humus of mother earth. It is the amniotic fluid bathing our souls for healing. It is out of that silence alone # the Spirit#s silence # that truth springs, and with truth, justice. And with justice, peace, and the healing touch of love.COP is upon us. Amid all the noisy voices, which kind of silence will we choose  Which kind of silence will we permit  Complicity, or graciousness Mercy and peace have met together,

title: kintyre holiday park expansion is creating new jobs
story: The £, project by Machrihanish Holiday Park will improve the site#s accommodation and facilities, increasing the number of holiday homes available to rent and buy.A sports court will be created, along with a new reception building.Accessibility improvements are being made, and ramps installed for toilet and shower facilities.The project will enable the company to grow by increasing the number of the park#s holiday home pitches from  to  over the next three years, complementing its existing  touring pitches.The improvements have helped to safeguard the existing . full time equivalentjobs at the park and have created a further four FTE posts.Recruitment for another three FTE roles is also planned for .Machrihanish Holiday Park forms part of the re-emerging holiday resort village of Machrihanish.The current owners have been investing in the park continuously since , transforming it from a two-star to a four-star park.The business has benefited from growth in demand for self-catering staycations.With this growth set to continue, the park is expected to benefit further from the staycation market.#There has been strong demand for self-catering, touring and camping holidays in Scotland since lockdown has ended and Kintyre has a lot to offer tourists looking for wide open spaces, miles of beaches, world-class golf and famous distilleries,# said Ian Aitkin of Machrihanish Holiday Park.#Our improvement project, with help from HIE, will enable us to expand and improve the park, providing visitors with five-star facilities.#Morag Goodfellow, HIE#s area manager for Argyll and the Islands, said: #Tourism has had a very dficult time but is also key to our region#s recovery.#The resilience and commitment shown by businesses in the sector has been amazing. Many continue to adapt, innovate and provide memorable and enjoyable experiences for visitors.#Machrihanish Holiday Park is a great example. With Argyll in an ideal position to benefit from the rise in staycations, from people across Scotland and the UK, it has taken the initiative to capitalise on this market growth.#This very welcome project will enhance the wider visitor offering, help attract more visitors and encourage longer stays in the area.#As well as supporting valuable jobs in a rural area, the expected increase in visitors is also likely to benefit other local businesses.#We are very pleased to be able to provide support and look forward to continuing to work with the business as they implement the plans.#Machrihanish Holiday Park is open for holiday home and hot-tub lodge rentals throughout the winter.Visit campkintyre or call    for more information or to book a break.

title: support argyll businesses through new gift card scheme
story: Many would like to support local businesses by shopping locally but may be struggling to find the perfect present.A new, local gt card scheme could provide the answer.Argyll and Bute local gt cards are now available to buy, giving people another way to spend locally and help support businesses in their communities.The card works in the same way as a gt voucher but instead of just one shop or destination, it allows the recipient to shop at a huge range of independent businesses and visitor attractions in the area.From restaurants, hotels and gt shops to bike hire, attractions and toy shops, the cards makes the perfect present for those who are hard to buy for.The gt cards are available to buy from scotlandgtslocal product argyll-bute-gt-card#The new Argyll and Bute gt card is a great new weapon in our fightback from the impact of Covid- on our communities,# said Councillor Robin Currie, policy lead for the economy and rural growth.#By local businesses and customers getting behind it, we will not only provide an immediate injection of cash, but lay the foundations for a stronger future, while highlighting the brilliant and innovative businesses we have here.#We#ve had a great response from local businesses who have already signed up. We#re now urging customers to help support your local area and buy a gt card to help people shop local.#Delivered by Scotland#s Towns Partnership – the organisation spearheading the Scotland Loves Local campaign – alongside Perth-based fintech Miconex, the programme is the first scheme of its scale in the country, giving every region the opportunity to launch its own local gt card.Businesses can register to accept the card at www.lovelocal.scot gtcard

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: former-guides-celebrated-90-years-combined-service
story: Margaret Craigie and Frances Monaghan, from Musselburgh, have both been members of the guild ndash which offers social opportunities and supports Girlguiding ndash for  years, having joined in .They received their badges from Lorraine Dickson, East Lothian County Commissioner, at a presentation at the Fisherrow Centre on South Street where the guild meets. Afterwards, a lsquosilhouettersquo quiz was enjoyed, followed by cake and tea.The Trefoil Guild, which is open to women and men over the age of , also supports Scouting.Members meet with friends, develop interests, tackle new challenges, enjoy outings and holidays together. They help Girlguiding at district, ision, county, region, UK and international level.Margaret Craigie joined the Brownies in Musselburgh in  and went on to become a Guide. She became a Brownie Guider in the rd Musselburgh Brownies in the s.Frances was a Brownie and Guide in Campbeltown. In Musselburgh, she was an adult helper with the th Musselburgh Brownie pack.Frances said that when she moved to Musselburgh after she married, and as a new mum, she found friendship with the guild, which had a membership of nearly  in the s. She also enjoyed helping to arrange outings and Christmas meals over the years.

title: comedy-film-music-theatre-brunton-next-days
story: Midlothian comedian Eric Davidson brings his style of humour to The Brunton today . A regular at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, his poetry and musical parody has had audiences spellbound with his ldquoclever satirical wordplay.Classic lunchtime theatre is back, offering company, soup and a sandwich, and a short play. Rapturersquos new production of The Dock Brief tells the story of budgie fancier Herbert Fowle, who murdered his we because she laughed too much. The production, written by John Mortimer , stars Scottish theatre legend and award-winning performer John Bett as Morgenhall. It is live on stage this Saturday .A classical lunchtime concert on Tuesday will be performed by Toronto-born musician Tim Beattie, who has won prizes at international guitar competitions in many countries. Now a star student at the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, he brings a programme of romantic music for guitar .The midweek movie next Wednesdayis Respect . Jenner Hudson stars as Queen of Soul Aretha Franklin in this epic biopic from director Liesl Tommy.Audiences, meanwhile, can relive the magic of the s with nine chart-topping acts at lsquoSixties Gold: the Ultimate Line Uprsquo on November , at .pm and .pm.It stars The Tremeloes, Mamas and Papas UK, Hermanrsquos Hermits, The Marmalade, PJ Proby, Dave Berry, Vanity Fare and Gerryrsquos Pacemakers.The Tremeloes have sold in excess of  million records worldwide, with their huge number one hits Silence Is Golden, Suddenly You Love Me, Even The Bad Times Are Good andNumber One.Hermanrsquos Hermits formed in Manchester in , chalked up  hit singles,  hit albums, appeared in three major movies and have sold in excess of  million records.Marmalade were the champions of the Scottish Beat in  PJ Proby was first invited to the UK by The Beatles Dave Berry had chart-topping hit The Crying Game Mamas and Papas UK will be performing songs including Calornia Dreaminrsquo and Gerryrsquos Pacemakers will perform hits including Yoursquoll Never Walk Alone.Tickets and information can be found at thebrunton

title: ban-motorcyclist-drove-grossly-excessive-speeds-a1
story: Richard Montgomery, of High Street, was caught driving a motorcycle dangerously by travelling at well over the speed limit on the A near to Gladsmuir.The -year-old pleaded guilty to the offence during an appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Monday.Sherf Matthew Auchencloss handed Montgomery an interim driving ban and deferred sentence for background reports to later this month.Montgomery, a director of a golf tour business, admitted driving the motorcycle at grossly excessive speeds on the A on September  last year.

title: winter-wonderland-coming-gosford-house-december
story: The Winter Wonderland event will take place at Gosford House, near Longniddry, between December  and .The festive set-up will feature vintage fairground rides, a Christmas tree maze, and a marketplace for independent Scottish brands.Tickets for the wonderland must be pre-booked in advance, via the website roguevillage

title: swimming-pool-mercat-gait-centre-closing-maintenance
story: The competition pool will be closed from next Saturdayuntil December .Other facilities at the centre will still be accessible to the public, barring any minor closures to accommodate the maintenance works.A spokesperson for the Mercat Gait Centre said: ldquoPlease keep in mind that you can still use your membership, swim tickets or other means of access at any enjoyleisure location.ldquoGive us a call for any questions or concerns.

title: girls-tranent-colts-help-cheer-scotland-victory-hampden-park
story: Youngsters from Tranent Coltsrsquo under-s team up to the under-s travelled to Hampden Park to see Scotland, including Dunbarrsquos Rachael Boyle, take on Hungary.Pedro Martinez Losarsquos team kept up their  per cent record in qualication as they look to reach the World Cup for just the second time.Christy Grimshaw put the hosts in front before Hungary equalised early in the second half.Captain Rachel Corsie was on hand, though, to score in the dying seconds to send the Tartan Army faithful home happy.Derek Little, who is involved with the girls academy at the club, thanked AC Coaches for the transport.He said: ldquoA lot of the kids donrsquot get to see things like this in their le.ldquoI got an email from Scottish Womenrsquos Football askingwe were interested in taking some tickets and I thought we could do something. Once I got the message out, we got a fantastic reaction.ldquoWe met at Ross High and the girls were impeccably behaved on the bus and at Hampden.ldquoAll the girls enjoyed it.ldquoEverybody loves a last-minute winner, especially in your favour.ldquoIt was a great day and hopefully it will happen again in the near future.Scotlandrsquos qualying campaign continues later this month when they welcome Ukraine to Hampden.

title: pictures-volunteers-help-plant-thousands-trees-extension-butterdean-wood
story: Butterdean Wood, near Gladsmuir, saw schoolchildren and corporate partners join Woodland Trust Scotland in the tree planting over several days last week, culminating in a community day on Saturday, when about  volunteers of all ages turned out to help plant trees.George Anderson, of Woodland Trust Scotland, said: ldquoHuge thanks to everyone who planted with us over the week.ldquoThere were some very wet days but people threw themselves into the task regardless. We hope people will keep coming back over the years to see how their trees are doing.We hope to offer more public planting opportunities at the wood early next year.The planting sees Butterdean Wood extended into two new fields, using funding support from Bank of Scotland. The trees are mostly oak but also include alder, birch, holly, hazel and rowan.Alastair Seaman, Woodland Trust Scotland director, said: ldquoWe are so grateful that our partnership with Bank of Scotland has allowed us to add this new area of woodland. It will be a marvellous haven for people and wildle but also a carbon store to help in the fight against climate change.Philip Grant, chairman of Lloyds Banking Grouprsquos Scottish executive committee, said: ldquoOver the next  years, Woodland Trust Scotland and Bank of Scotland will plant thousands of trees together as part of a wider partnership across the country. I am delighted we are able to support the creation of new woodland at Butterdean as part of this partnership.An online vote saw the name Butterdean Brocksden chosen, in honour of a large and long-established badger sett nearby.

title: sections-roads-cockenzie-port-seton-closed-resurfacing
story: Works on Links Road, from Fishers Road to  Links Road, will run from Monday until next Friday .During the works, temporary traffic signals will be in place, parking restrictions will be signed and coned, refuse collection will be unaffected and pedestrian access will be maintained.Phase two of works will see Links Road, from number  to outside number , closed to all vehicles from November  to .Vehicular access will not be available on this section, parking restrictions will be signed and coned, and bus services will follow the designated ersion route ndash East Lorimer Place to Alder Road to Longcraigs for eastbound, and reverse for westbound, until meeting its normal route.During the second phase of works, pedestrian access will be maintained and refuse collection will also be unaffected.Access required for businesses in the Viewforth Seton Place Park Road areas during phase two of the works should use alternative turnings into these areas, as the junctions onto B Links Road will be closed off.Residential access to Barracks Street during phase two will be limited during the construction process.Residents are advised to park outwith the area to limit car movements during working hours between .am and pm.For any queries or specic access requirements, email roadservices@eastlothian.gov.uk or telephone  .

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-november-1-5-1996-1971-1921
story: THE ceiling at a hall in Prestonpans was damaged during stormy weather, reported the East Lothian Courier on November , .Stormy weather which hit the district on Monday caused serious damage to the Salvation Army Hall in Prestonpans.Local Brownies had a narrow escape when a corridor ceiling caved in an hour after their meeting had finished, but luckily the building was empty when it happened.The collapse was caused by rainwater which had collected through a leak in the roof during the storms.The building, in Kirk Street, was closed all week to enable builders to make the area safe.Captain John McAffrey said: ldquoWith all the wind and rain it was just the final straw.ldquoWater collected in the ceiling and pulled it down.ldquoThe roof itself has not fallen in, it is just a corridor ceiling. We still have structural problems with the roof in the main hall, but this was not the result of the storm damage, and it will be out service until structural engineers declare it safe.lsquoSIX hurt in accidentrsquo was a headline in The Haddingtonshire Courier on November , .An ex-police superintendent at Haddington and five of his passengers were slightly inconvenienced when his car was in a collision with a lorry in East Lothian on Wednesday.Ex-Supt, Alexander David Craig , of  Dunbar Road, Haddington, was driving his car west on the Haddington-Pencaitland road near Letham Holdings when it was in collision with a lorry parked broadside across the road.Mr Craig and his passengers were taken to Roodlands Hospital, Haddington, for a check-up but were not detained.The driver of the lorry, Mr William George Deans , a High Street, East Linton, was unhurt.The car was extensively damaged.A STABBING case was reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on November , .In Haddington Sherf Court, on Monday, William Murphy, labourer, Standalane, pleaded guilty to having on Saturday night, nd October, stabbed Neil McLean, labourer, in a bothy at Standalane.The Fiscal stated that the accused and McLean and their wives, along with a man named Young, had all been drinking.An altercation occurred between accused and McLean, who rose to put an end to the quarrel.Murphy, who had the kne in his hand, rose to his feet and immediately attacked McLean by striking him with the kne on the face and the arms.

title: used-goods-festival-haddington-aims-make-secondhand-first-choice
story: Non-profit organisation Lil is looking to bring the community together to donate and sell good-quality, pre-loved items.Donations will be gratefully received by Lil at its High Street home by Monday so the items can be quarantined, priced and ready for sale.Louise Hastie, Lil director, was looking forward to welcoming buyers and stallholders along to the festival at the Maitlandfield House Hotel.She said: ldquoWith donations rolling in and refreshments at the ready, the festival is set to be a great family day out, where you can knock some items off your Christmas shopping list and bank yourself some secondhand treasure.ldquoDonrsquot forget your shopping bags!ldquoBuying secondhand not only benefits our pockets, it increases the lespan of a product, resulting in less production and less waste.ldquoAt Lil we want everyone to be able to make secondhand their first choice and are working with local referral partners to make the festival accessible to all, regardless of budget.Items being sold at the festival will include childrenrsquos and adultsrsquo clothing and footwear, baby equipment, sports kit, soft furnishings, toys, books, bikes, gardening tools and equipment, as well as garden plants, seeds and produce.Buyers must use only vouchers, which can be bought from Lilrsquos website, the High Street premises or the venue, to pay for goods.Unused vouchers can be refunded on the day or used to buy eco-friendly products at the Lil shop.All funds raised on the day will go back into supporting local community eco initiatives run by Lil.There is also the option of a   split scheme for sellers.Zero Waste Scotland cites that about four-fths of Scotlandrsquos footprint comes from the products and materials people manufacture, use and throw away.The average Scot consumes . tonnes of materials every year ndash the equivalent of kg per week on average.Louise said: ldquoBy making secondhand our first choice, we can cut that drastically.The reuse festival and secondhand market will be open on November , .am-pm.

title: tims-tales-dark-stormy-night
story: Well,Irsquom being honest, this paints an overly romantic picture of family togetherness, the reality is often very dferent characterised by a screaming match between siblings competing for limited technical devices, with myself trying to justy why Irsquom using the last available laptop to write.I am aware that screen time has become a real issue for us as a family. It was the lockdown which entrenched this: screens were the way to connect with people, friends, family and even school learning.They became the default activity and I believe itrsquos become an unhealthy addiction for us and as the nights have drawn in, with less opportunity for outside activity and walks in nature, this addiction has the risk of becoming even worse.I know screens are not all bad, they have benefits and advantages too. . . hell knows, I spend so much time on screens myself.I think we can be too hard on ourselves at times and Irsquom aware of that. Irsquod go to say that some screen time is now important for a iety of reasons. I also recognise that in the last two years they have become a leline for many people.But lately I have been trying my best to practise what I preach as a storyteller. I want to find ways to wean my kids, and myself, from screens to find a healthier balance, a more personal connection which lts our mental health rather than sapping it.Itrsquos not been easy. When the kids are asked to come off screens, they often explode with what I call screen rage. Itrsquos aswe are cutting an umbilical cord and removing their le support system, and they must fight and protest to restore it. The drama is predictable and tiring, but the good news is itrsquos usually relatively short-lived. Irsquove discovered that kids are eventually glad when they have been taken off excessive use of screens.The trick is to have something engaging to replace it with, as well as to model it myself. Thatrsquos the thing, itrsquos so easy to be a hypocrite to tell my kids itrsquos the end of screen time, while using my phone or writing on my laptop.ldquoBut you are still on a screen, dad! was the rebuke from my astute eight-year-old daughter recently. And she was right, so the rules have to apply to me and my we too.We are slowly getting there. We have no screens before bedtime now, instead a family storytelling session. The hardest part has been establishing the routine with so much to do. But now the kids look forward to it and help make the living room cosy in preparation.And I feel the benefits too. It helps me close down that ruminator in my head, which constantly reminds me of how much I have to do, emails I need to reply to, deadlines I need to meet. Instead I become focused on the moment, on the fact Irsquom sharing the attention of my loved ones and we are all telling stories.I know this now does sound overly romantic, but the thing is nothing can compare to these moments of connection, such as the magic of listening to my wee boy tell another spontaneous chapter of his tale of the haunted pizzeria, or listening to my girls weave a story rooted in their experiences of the day or a favoured fable from their earlier childhood. And Irsquove discovered my we Kate is a good storyteller when given the opportunity.Maybe it felt awkward at first, that we were doing it because I thought we should be rather than because we all wanted to. But that awkwardness soon gave way to excited expectation and genuine enjoyment of the experience. And the darkness helps, itrsquos a blanket which adds atmosphere and allows us to use fairy lights and candles, so in that sense the cold and dark of this time of year is a huge advantage: itrsquos the season for cosy storytelling.The flicker of screens still shine more regularly than the storytelling candles in our house. But the balance is slowly changing. Hallowersquoen helped, it seemed such a natural time for storytelling. And I think I can say we have now established our storytelling sessions as a regular family tradition. When it happens, it feels like ancient magic has entered our house.I run storytelling sessions with parents and many share the challenges I recognise in my own family. All families are dferent, of course, and no child is the same. Buta family storytelling tradition can be established, everyone feels the benefits. Evenonly every now and then, they will be times of real connection that everyone will remember.Soyou fancy trying it and would like my short guide with some reflections and tips, drop me an email. Or maybe you have tips and experiences yoursquod like to share recently, a parent told me that bath time was storytelling time in her house, as she sat on the toilet telling favoured tales to her young children! Great idea!Now is the perfect season to give it a gohellip for as many a storyteller has said: ldquohellipit was a dark, stormy nighthellip

title: residents-tired-houses-272-get-green-light
story: The western edge of Haddington has changed considerably in recent years, with hundreds of homes built at Letham Mains, Gateside and Dovecot.About  homes are being constructed at Letham Mains, with the latest development ndash from Taylor Wimpey, Mactaggart and Mickel, Andrew Bain and Classhappy ndash set to add another  houses and  flats.The development, in the south-west corner of the site, off the A, was first put forward more than two years ago and given the go-ahead by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department last month.More than  new homes at Letham Mains have been given the green light, despite concerns about infrastructure not matching the pace of development in the townThe townrsquos community council was said to be ldquolargely supportive of the latest application but did highlight problems.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officerrsquos report notes: ldquoHowever, they are concerned thatworks to extend Knox Academy need to be progressed before any further developments are granted planning permission andthat this development should make a financial contribution to fund that extension. The residents of Haddington are tired of more houses being built without matching infrastructure to accommodate the increased population.Calls have been made to ensure Knox Academy can cope as more houses are given the go ahead in Haddington. Picture: Google MapsConditions attached to the approval mean the applicants will have to provide more than pound. million towards ious improvements.Making up the majority of the seven-figure sum is a contribution to the council of pound,, towards additional accommodation at Knox Academy and the recently completed Letham Mains Primary and Nursery School.A further pound, is to go towards enhancing existing sports facilities in the area, and pound, towards the cost of a seven-a-side sports pitch.Finally, nearly pound, is for ious transport improvements, including junctions on the A.Pauline Mills, land and planning director for Taylor Wimpey East Scotland, said: ldquoWe will always work very closely with local authorities to ensure that we meet their requirements to mitigate any impact on local infrastructure that occurs as a result of our developments, and this was an important aspect of our detailed Section  discussions with East Lothian Council.ldquoThe terms of the Section  agreement for Letham Holdings is fully in line with the council policy on developer contributions for new development.ldquoWe work hard to ensure that we target our new developments in areas that are well connected, sustainable and integrate well with the existing community, and our development at Letham Holdings is no exception.And she added: ldquoAs required by council policy and our Section  agreement, we will contribute over pound. million toward improvements to education, sporting provision and transport in Haddington, and will deliver an impressive new community to call home.More than  members of the public, along with Haddington and District Amenity Society , objected to the scheme.Concerns included the potential increase in vehicles using Letham Mains Lane and the A, which links Haddington to Pencaitland.Developers show access will come from Letham Lane, as well as the existing Letham Mains development.Taylor Wimpeyrsquos section of the site would be made up of  homes, with  affordable.Private housing would consist of six two-bedroom,  three-bedroom and  four-bedroom properties, while the affordable housing would be an equal mix of  one and two-bedroom flats,  three-bedroom properties and two four-bedroom properties.Meanwhile, Mactaggart and Mickelrsquos area would be  private units and  affordable homes.The private development would feature  four-bedroom,  three-bedroom and  two-bedroom flats, and the affordable section would be four four-bedroom, four three-bedroom,  two-bedroom and eight one-bedroom properties.Councillor Tom Trotter, who represents Haddington on East Lothian Council, stressed the importance of infrastructure matching the housing developments.He said: ldquoWe stay in a beautul part of East Lothian ndash all of East Lothian is beautul ndash but the simple fact is it is more residential than anything .ldquoThe long-term aim is for sustainable companies to create jobs for local people.ldquoA high percentage of people are commuting to Edinburgh and further afield, which is not very good for the environment.

title: green-fingered-volunteer-goes-purple-polio-day
story: Fiona Wells is a member of the Bass Rock Community Group, itself part of Rotary in Great Britain and Ireland.On October , Rotary marked World Polio Day ndash the organisation has been raising money to eradicate polio, a serious viral infection, throughout the world since .It works alongside the World Health Organisationand the Bill Gates Foundation. The disease is currently prevalent in only two countries: Afghanistan and Pakistan.The colour purple symbolises the fight against polio, so Fiona planted purple pansies in tubs at the Lime Grove Community Garden in North Berwick last week.Fiona Wells planted the purple pansies at the Lime Green Community GardenRichard Rogers, a member of the Bass Rock Community Group, said: ldquoA few purple pansies were planted to give some colour through the winter.ldquoThis was done as part of making the garden enjoyable for residents and to raise the publicrsquos awareness of this ongoing campaign.ldquoFor those interested in donating, please go to the Rotary End Polio Now website.ldquoThe primary focus of the Bass Rock Community Group is our own community here in North Berwick.ldquoHowever, we wish to commend the work Rotary does in communities across the world.ldquoIt is not that long ago that polio was so prevalent in this country and we recognise how fortunate we are that this terrible disease is now no longer here.

title: letter-week-marion-slandered-200-years
story: This old chestnut has appeared many times over the years in articles and books on local history and witchcraft, and derives from the report on Spott written by the parish minister for the late th century lsquoOld Statistical Accountrsquo.In his report, the minister John Martin says that the Spott Kirk Session minutes record the referral of Marion Lillie to the civil magistrate in  on a charge of supposed witchcraft and that in  the minutes record: ldquoMany witches burnt at the top of Spott Loan.Mr Martin was, however, wrong.The Spott Kirk Session minutes are exceptionally legible and clear, and they make no reference whatsoever in  to witch burning at Spott Loan or anywhere .Nor is there any mention of Marion Lillie in .However, in , Marion and her son complained to the kirk session that she was being slandered as a witch.A y investigation followed in which it came to light that Marion did indeed have that reputation locally.Since kirk sessions were not qualied to try witchcraft cases, the session passed the matter on to the civil magistrate, as they were required to do.However, there is no evidence of the case being taken any further and the Spott records show that Marion died a natural death in April  and was buried in Spott kirkyard with the usual ceremonial trappings of bell and mortcloth.Unfortunately, many writers on Scottish witchcraft make the mistake of simply repeating what other writers have written, instead of going to the original records to see what was really going on.Poor Marion has thus been slandered in print as an executed witch for over  years, when half an hour spent actually reading the church records of Spott could have revealed the truth.Until recently, a plaque at the Witchesrsquo Stone stated that Marion Lillie was burnt there, but this has now been replaced by one which makes no mention of her.It may well be that the Witchesrsquo Stone marks the execution of a witch, or witches, but the victim was not Marion Lillie, and any such execution was neither in  nor in , which in any case would be suspiciously late for witch burning in the Lothians.David RobertsonForthview RoadLongniddry

title: old-musselburgh-club-members-celebrate-60th-anniversary
story: Held at the Ravelston House Hotel, top table guests included Alaric Bonthron, who proposed the Toast to the Burgh.Councillor Andy Forrest, Depute Provost of East Lothian, gave the reply.Club member George C Cunningham proposed the Toast to the Guests, which was replied to by Drew Johnstone.The eveningrsquos activities were chaired by president David Stillie, who, at the end of the meal, presented his successor Ivor Highley with the chain of office.A vote of thanks for an ldquoentertaining evening was proposed by vice-president Kenny McKenzie.

title: pedestrian-crossing-outside-blindwells-development
story: The crossing has replaced temporary traffic lights at the site.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoAs part of the Blindwells development, a new junction has been created from the A with traffic signals including pedestrian crossings.ldquoWe are liaising with the contractor on post-installation checks to ensure the traffic signals meet our requirements and will arrange for them to be operational at the earliest opportunity.

title: hound-music-causing-stir-gullane
story: Bill Hudson, of Muirfield Steading, adopted Border collie Lottie when his previous pet, Roxy, passed away.And when Lottie proved to be something of a mischief-maker, chewing through his shoes, his work notes and two sets of headphones, Bill decided to harness her energy with the power of music.He told the Courier: ldquoShersquos absolutely running me ragged!ldquoBut I was watching this programme that showed a Border collie that had been trained to get a beer from the fridge.ldquoAnd I thought,I could train a dog to do something like that, shersquod be doing something shersquos born to do ndash be a sheepdog.Bill Hudson and Lottie the puppyBut rather than fetch beer, Lottie is being trained to sing the blues.Bill, , explained: ldquoShersquos not quite got the hang of it yet but shersquos getting there, singing at the right times.ldquoShe managed to play a chord on the guitar ndash I was strumming away and she came up and started twanging the strings with her teeth.ldquoAnd I thought, well, thatrsquos not a bad note, actually!ldquoI do recordings at home and Irsquove looped one of her barks, and Irsquom trying to record her, because you can get any sound and then use it.ldquoShersquos got potential.And Lottie is in safe musical hands, as Billrsquos uncle was William Blezard, musical director to Noeumll Coward, Marlene Dietrich and Joyce Grenfell.Bill Hudson and Lottie the puppy.Bill said: ldquoHe also worked with Sir Laurence Olivier, wrote film music for Pinewood, and the music for BBCrsquos Play School, with Johnny Ball and Brian Cant.Bill, a freelance sub editor by day, is himself a musician, playing open mic nights and writing, producing and selling music. He said: ldquoI stream it on Spoty and SoundCloud too. It gets played anywhere from Egypt to Toronto ndash things Irsquod forgotten Irsquod even written!Gullane residents should be on the lookout for a carol-singing Lottie this Christmas!

title: volunteer-efforts-never-ever-forgotten
story: A town resilience group set up to help vulnerable people in the national lockdown last year saw volunteers deliver hot meals, collect shopping and prescriptions, and even walk pets and maintain gardens.Jack Worden, a member of the townrsquos community council, took time to praise fellow community councillor Rab Moran, who also volunteers for the townrsquos Our Community Kitchen and Blooming Haddington.Mr Worden said: ldquoPeople who know what you do really appreciate the contribution you make to the town.However, Mr Moran also stressed that it was a team effort.Speaking at a recent meeting of the community council, he added: ldquoThere are a lot of other people who do a hell of a lot of work as well.ldquoPat Lemmon and all those people in the resilience group did amazing work and they should never, ever be forgotten.

title: lottery-funding-community-connections-group
story: North Berwick Coastal Community Connections , launched in , was set up to identy those in the community who were experiencing loneliness and social isolation, with a view to befriending them, building their confidence and helping them make connections.Until now funded by North Berwick Trust and East Lothian Councilrsquos One Council Funding, it reaches out to people in Aberlady, Ballencrieff, Dirleton, Drem, Fenton Barns, Gullane, Kingston, North Berwick and Whitekirk.In March , the project had to adapt to the pandemic, with many of its members shielding.Project officer Carol Stobie developed befriending and lsquobuddy walksrsquo services, as gatherings were forced to come to a halt.Robert Burgon, NBCCC co-chair, said: ldquoWe are delighted that the project has received this support and recognition.ldquoThere is possibly even more need than ever for a project of this nature as so many people in our community have experienced the long-lasting impact of the pandemic.ldquoWe look forward to developing our services as we address social isolation and loneliness, across all age groups, in the coastal ward.Carol added: ldquoWersquore absolutely thrilled that funding has been secured.ldquoItrsquos been a tough  months, with many of our members struggling with greater isolation than ever, and new referrals steeply increasing over this time.ldquoNow we can plan to reinstate some of our original core face-to-face work, including Scone Cafe at the Abbey Church Hall, and to reopen our partnership activities with many other community groups.ldquoThis includes a lsquocompassionate neighboursrsquo project to support people with a terminal diagnosis, in partnership with North Berwick Compassionate Communities.ldquoWersquoll also be able to sustain our newer one-to-one services, with befriending and buddy walks for the most vulnerable members.ldquoWersquore hoping to recruit a third team member for administration and communications tasks.To find out more about NBCCC, contact Carol on   or nbc-communityconnections@outlook

title: recycling-first-boosted-top-accolade
story: Recycling First, which has been running for more than  years, has been successful in being recertied by Revolve, the national reuse quality standard offered by Zero Waste Scotland.The Macmerry-based organisation, which offers used items such as household furniture and white goods at competitive prices, first achieved Revolve certication in , gaining national recognition as an organisation encouraging more people to consider buying used goods.Revolve aims to increase reuse by improving professionalism, customer experience and visibility of reuse organisations.Tom Logan, the project manager at Recycling First, was delighted to receive the recognition.He said: ldquoThe high standards we maintain mean we can be sure our customer experience is now at a level which rivals high street shopping.Iain Gulland, chief executive at Zero Waste Scotland, highlighted the importance of reusing goods.He said: ldquoWe want to increase the appeal of reuse, develop a sector of customer-focussed organisations selling high-quality products, and increase shoppersrsquo confidence in buying previously owned goods.ldquoThis will not only help Scotland make the best possible use of the resources we have, but it will also generate income and jobs for the local economy from goods that would otherwise have cost money to dispose of.

title: celeb-line-confirmed-louise-minchin-adam-woodyatt-set-star
story: The reality show that sees celebrities compete in ious Bushtucker trials willto Wales for a second year after Covid- has prevented the contestants jetting off to the camp in Australia for the last  series.The show will be ing to Gwrych Castle in Abergele where the  celebrities will live and compete in ious gruesome challenges.The Sun has revealed which stars will be taking place in the competition this year. The star also took part in Celebrity SAS: Who Dares Wins last year.Naughty Boy" alt"East Lothian Courier: Naughty Boy " class"editor-image"Naughty Boy British DJ Naughty Boy, real name Shahid Khan, has supposedly signed up to join the castle this year.Danny Miller" alt"East Lothian Courier: Danny Miller " class"editor-image"Danny Miller Danny Miller, best known for his role on Emmerdale as Aaron Dingle is another star rumoured to be making an appearance in Wales this year.Louise Minchin" alt"East Lothian Courier: Louise Minchin " class"editor-image"Louise Minchin Former BBC Breakfast host, Louise Minchin could be ing to early mornings in the Welsh castle as she is rumoured to be taking part in this yearrsquos show.Matty Lee" alt"East Lothian Courier: Matty Lee alongside Tom Daley " class"editor-image"Matty Lee alongside Tom Daley British er and Olympic gold medallist Matty Lee will be taking on new challenges in this yearrsquos show.DJ Snoochie#@snoochieshy takes over our late-night show Monday-Thursday pm-am ####### pic ibYxIMWRadioExtra host, DJ Snoochie, also known as Cheyenne Davide, could be making an appearance in Wales at the end of this month.Adam Woodyatt" alt"East Lothian Courier: Adam Woodyatt " class"editor-image"Adam Woodyatt And last, but certainly not least, British actor Adam Woodyatt, known for his portrayal of Ian Beale in EastEnders, is said to be on this yearrsquos line-up.Irsquom a Celeb s to screens on Sunday,  November at pm on ITV.

title: covid-scotland-over-50s-can-book-booster-mid-november
story: The booster scheme means that certain groups will get a third dose of the Covid vaccine, in an attempt to boost immunity to the virus throughout winter.Government officials around the UK have been urging people to get their booster jags as hospitalisations with Covid begin to creep up.And with the increased circulation of colds, flus and viruses during the winter months, getting vaccinated could help to reduce load on the NHS.Heres what you need to know about who can get the booster jab and when you can book it...Over-s in Scotland will be invited to book the Covid booster online from mid-November.So far, booster vaccines have been given to people in care homes and invites have been sent to those over- and people who are clinically vulnerable.Front care health workers have also been invited to book their Covid booster jabs on the NHS inform Scotland website.Over-s are also eligible for the booster jag, and the NHS Scotland website states that they will be able to book online from mid-November.Adult carers and unpaid carers aged + will also be able to book online from mid-November.The following groups are eligible for the booster vaccine in Scotland:All over-s who wereseverely immunosuppressed at the time of their first or second jab, including those with leukaemia, advanced HIV and recent organ transplants, will also receive a third dose of the vaccine, however this is independent from the booster scheme.

title: covid-scotland-over-50s-can-book-booster-mid-november
story: The booster scheme means that certain groups will get a third dose of the Covid vaccine, in an attempt to boost immunity to the virus throughout winter.Government officials around the UK have been urging people to get their booster jags as hospitalisations with Covid begin to creep up.And with the increased circulation of colds, flus and viruses during the winter months, getting vaccinated could help to reduce load on the NHS.Heres what you need to know about who can get the booster jab and when you can book it...Over-s in Scotland will be invited to book the Covid booster online from mid-November.So far, booster vaccines have been given to people in care homes and invites have been sent to those over- and people who are clinically vulnerable.Front care health workers have also been invited to book their Covid booster jabs on the NHS inform Scotland website.Over-s are also eligible for the booster jag, and the NHS Scotland website states that they will be able to book online from mid-November.Adult carers and unpaid carers aged + will also be able to book online from mid-November.The following groups are eligible for the booster vaccine in Scotland:All over-s who wereseverely immunosuppressed at the time of their first or second jab, including those with leukaemia, advanced HIV and recent organ transplants, will also receive a third dose of the vaccine, however this is independent from the booster scheme.

title: 5-points-covid-scotland-update-today
story: The first minister was absent from Parliament again this week as she continued with COP hosting duties, with the second week of the climate summit well underway.Last weekhealth secretary Humza Yousaf echoed concerns raised by the first minister in a previous update regarding the rising numbers of hospitalisations with Covid, which reflected the viruss prevalence among the older population.Warnings were issued before COP suggesting that cases could surge after the summit due to the influx of people to the city.However, the Scottish government has repeatedly confirmed it is doing everything it can to mitigate the chances of a rise in infection rate.Following another Covid statement, heres what we learned from todays announcement...A further , cases of Covid were recorded over the past -hours in Scotland,meaning cases continue to hover around the , mark.Cases have recently plateaued around this figure following a decline after a surge in the summer due to the easing of restrictions.The deputy first minister confirmed that as of today,  million boosters and third vaccines had been administered in Scotland.Theres a risk that the spread of the virus could surge againthe past pattern is anything to go by, according to John Swinney.He expressed concern that Covid case rates could rise in coming weeks due to Christmas mingling indoors and with loved ones as the weather gets colder and the festive period nearer.He confirmed that the government was considering whether to extend the Covid certication scheme to indoor hospitality venues and other areas.However, the deputy first minister added that no decisions on this have yet been made.The three weekly review of the measures currently in place will take place a week today, and John Swinney said they could not rule out reintroducing or strengthening measures.The deputy first minister also took the opportunity to urge people to stick to current guidelines, as well as getting vaccinated and taking regular lateral flow tests.As of November , Covid positivity at COP based on lateral flow tests upon entry to the blue zone was around .%.He acknowledged however we are only just past the halfway point of the conference and confirmed another update would be given following the end of the summit.

title: storm-wanda-met-office-forecast-scotland-week
story: Travelling across the Atlantic, the storm could weaken in force by the time it reaches British shores, however a Met Office forecaster has said that there remains uncertainty over how badly it could impact the UK.It all depends on whether the storm is picked up by the jet stream and how the two interact, according to forecaster Aiden McGivirn.He said there was some "uncertainty" over the storm "because it is associated with an area of low pressure that is moving towards Iceland."He added: "There is the possibility that Wanda will be picked up by the jet stream, andthe energy created by Wanda interacts with the jet stream in a certain way the jet stream will become more amplied."As Storm Wanda potentially heads towards the UK, heres the weather forecast for Scotland this week...It looks like Scotland will dodge most of the impact of Storm Wanda this week.Most of the country will remain largely dry for the rest of week, meaning we wont get the rain brought by Storm Wanda.However, that doesnt mean we will miss it completely, with gusty conditions expected nation wide.The next couple of days will see high winds up to mph in the north of the country.The east could see gusts around mph over the next fewdays before gales calm down for the remainder of the week.Gusts look set to peak in Glasgow on Friday at around mph in the early hours, while in the central belt it looks like winds will remain mainly steady throughout the week, peaking on Wednesday with mph gusts in Stirling.There have been lots of reports suggesting snow could hit Scotland in the coming weeks, but will it Currently, the Met Office does not predict snow forScotland over the next week, with temperatures expected to hover between - degrees in most areas.

title: runs-scotland-investigation-scotlands-corridors-power-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access to the people and organisationswith signicant influence over so many aspects of our lives.From the hundreds of secret lobbying meetings to who really runs Scotlands wind farms, whisky and media - the investigation will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two months here.Hundreds of meetings between Scottish ministers and multinationals, wealthy iniduals and other influentialorganisationswere left off the lobbying register in  due to loopholes in legislation, The Ferret can reveal.Analysis of Scottish Government ministersrsquoengagements in shows that meetings, potentially of key public interest, were not in the register, including those between ministers andcompaniesawarded multi-million poundUK and Scottish contracts to supply the NHS in the run-up to Covid-.Read the full scale of unrecorded discussions here.Professional lobbyists, including former politicians, advisors and a former minister have met with Scottish Government representatives on behalf of clients  times since March , The Ferret can reveal.Scotlandis home to dozens of public relations, think-tanks and consultancy firms, including several formed by or employing people who served in the upper echelons of government.Find out the whos who of professional lobbyists here.Questions have been raised over the power and influence of energycompaniesfollowing analysis by The Ferret revealing how key sectors dominate Scottish lobbying.The Ferretcategorisedorganisationsthat lobbied Scottish Government ministers since the register was introduced in  to increase transparency.Read the full exclusive analysis here.Bigbusinessincluding oil and renewable energy, farming, fishing, finance and whisky dominated Scotland Office ministersrsquo meetings last year, analysis by The Ferret has found.We looked at all external meetings logged in  by Alister Jack, Secretary of State forScotland, UK Government ministers for Scotland David Duguid and Iain Stewart, as well as Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, who was deputy Secretary of State until he resigned in May that year.Read the full report exclusively here.The number ofcompaniesregistered in tax havens investing in Scotland over the last decade has increased by nearly  per cent.Analysis of Scottish Governmentdataby The Ferret found that in  there were  firms registered in the Cayman Islands, Bermuda and British Virgin Islands operating, compared to  in . Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over poundbn.Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotlandrsquos biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately ownedoutwithScotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned bycompaniesoutside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailandrsquos richest man.The Ferret can reveal that of the Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used thelawto avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full storyhereFive privatecompanieswho employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotlandrsquos arms industry had thousands ofclosed doormeetings with the UK Government between  and .As part of TheFerretrsquosWho Runs Scotlandinvestigation we looked at firmsoperating in Scotlandrsquosdefenceindustry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over poundm in total last year, leading to ldquoexcessive pay gaps between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.In the course of ourresearchwe looked at the salaries ndash before bonuses or pension tops-up ndash of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish governmentpublic andhealthbodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotlandrsquos public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.Read the full story here.Influential bankers,retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotlandrsquos quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotlandrsquos public bodies.Some roles are unpaid, and manyworkextra hours intheirdevotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of Scottish Government public board positionshas also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  Thatrsquos been the central question of The Ferret and The Heraldrsquos week-long investigation.Along the way wersquove examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers ndash and who doesnrsquot.Find out the top most influential people in Scotland here.Scotlandrsquos biggest private landowner has been attacked as ldquomanipulative and ldquoundemocratic after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.A letter released under freedom of informationlawshows thatWildland Limitedmdash which runs three large estates acrossScotlandfor Danish billionaire,Anders Holch Povlsenmdash warned the former ruraleconomyminister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.Read the full story here.Scotlandneeds a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation ndash Who Runs Scotland ndash claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: scottish-politics-features-covid-sign-newsletters
story: Weve been expanding our newsletter service here at The Herald, and we want to take you through our new and improved offerings.You can subscribe to our newslettersyoure a registered user or a subscriber by heading to our sign up page and selecting your favourites.Every day, were giving you a rundown of who you can expect in our incredible Voices section.We go through the columnists of the day, giving a sneak peek into their musings - and well also showcase the fantastic illustrations from our in-house artist, Steven Camley, as well.In April, we launched a new evening political newsletter, Unspun, which promises readers an exclusive analysis of the day in Scottish politics - and a look at whats coming next.As Scotland deals with the aftermath of what was one of the most important Scottish elections in history, were bringing you top insight from some of our most popular contributors every weekday at pm.Wersquove enlisted the help of Alison Rowat on Tuesdays, Kevin McKenna on Wednesdays, Iain Macwhirter on Thursdays and Neil Mackay on Fridays.For all the latest coronavirus news in Scotland, including the latest figures and updates, make sure you subscribe to our Covid in Scotland newsletter, reaching inboxes at pm each day.Youll be given the latest figures in Scotland, and have all the latest news and analysis about the pandemic from our health correspondents at your fingertips.At pm, well take you through the stories our readers have been enjoying the most from that day.Well give you a rundown of the headlines and a preview of the pieces that have been getting our readers talking in our catch-up newsletter - perfect for your commute home.In addition to politics, fans of Scotlands arts and cultural scene are set to benefit from our brand new Herald Magazine newsletter, reaching inboxes every Saturday at pm.Written by assistant editor Garry Scott and senior features writer Susan Swarbrick, youll get the latest from our weekly Saturday magazine straight to your inbox, and our top picks from the pages.So sit back, relax, and get the latest straight to your inbox everyday by signing up here

title: green-scotland-can-read-investigation
story: From big-name polluters to Scotlandrsquos most deteriorating rivers and lochs, The Heraldrsquos exclusive, week-long investigation kicks off on Tuesday, October , to answer some of the crucial questions in the ongoing climate crisis.Hot off the back of the successfullsquoWho Runs Scotland rsquo series in July, no stone will be left unturned in The Herald and The Ferretrsquos joint bid to uncover wrongdoing, stimulate debate, and generate discussion.This special series will run in print and online all of this week, exclusively to our subscribers.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today.

title: scotland-ready-south-africa-test-saturday-says-john-dalziel
story: Dalziel revealed yesterday that the damaged rib suffered by hooker George Turner in the thminute of the Wallaby match does not appear to be as severe as initially feared, and with Stuart McInally also set to come back into the mix following an illness last week, there is a good chance that Ewan Ashman could drop out.The -year-old celebrated his international debut in style, scoring a spectacular try in that - win over Australia, but against arguably the most respected and feared forward units in world rugby, but he is still listed as an academy player at Sale Sharks and has played only  senior pro matches so far in his fledgling career.Ashman has established himself as a player with a big future, who is already capable of competing on the international stage, but it would be a big ask for him to front-up again versus the might of South Africa just six days after playing  minutes against Australia.Meanwhile, second-row Scott Cummings is also expected to be in the frame when the team to face South Africa is announced on Thursday after missing the first two matches of this Autumn Test series whilst rehabbing from an operation on his arm at the start of October.ldquoThere were a few knocks and bruises [after the Australia game], but we had some pleasing news this morning, to realise that nothing is as major as we thought last night, said Dalziel yesterday.ldquoThe guys will get through recovery protocols and medical checkouts today, but we have now massive concerns at all. Fingers crossed nothing develops later in the day.ldquoGeorge came off having felt a rib in a scrum, which can be uncomfortable, a pretty sharp pain, he added. ldquoBut therersquos been a huge turnaround with him this morning and hersquos bouncing about as normal. George is a resilient character and its good news. Wersquore pretty sure hersquos going to turn it around quicker than we thought yesterday.There is an obvious temptation to reward the players who got the job done against the worldrsquos third ranked team, in the cut-throat world of professional rugby,nobodyrsquos place in the teamis guaranteed.ldquoWersquove got to pick the right team to complement the challenges wersquoll face against South Africa, stated Dalziel. ldquoThey are very dferent to Australia who have that attack focus and want to play a lot of rugby, whereas with the South Africans it is a physical battle. Straight up and down. They are coming straight through the front door at us.ldquoSo, tactically, and selection-wise, wersquoll look at that.A lot of guys who were maybe quieter in that Tonga game [two weekends ago] have now put their hand up and performed.But when you look around the squad there may be guys who werenrsquot involved at the weekend who might be suited to this challenge, so no doubt there could be and probably will be a few changes around that.ldquoThe squad is growing all the time, and wersquore blessed as coaches to have the group wersquove got now through the good work which is going on at the pro teams and through the age grades, he added.ldquoWersquore able to keep building on that and young players are bouncing off each other. Wersquore seeing thatone player goes to the next level then wersquove got more players looking to push beyond that. Nobody is comfortable in any position.ldquoWersquove got real quality players missing out on selection, and it is hard for us to try and pick the right team for the right opposition now, while making sure that we are keeping everyone hungry, and making sure that people are getting opportunities when they deserve it.Despite the magnitude of the challenge Scotland face on Saturday Dalziel insisted that the team will go into the match believing they have nothing to fear.ldquoIrsquove been lucky enough to work with these players for a number of years, from the under-s onwards, he said. ldquoIrsquove seen them grow as men and itrsquos outstanding, the high standards they hold with each other.ldquoAs a group, they deal with setbacks, know the path theyrsquore on, and there is no ceiling.They want to grow and become that Scotland team that is consistent, that can win on the big occasion more often.ldquoTheyrsquore very humble and realise wersquore at the start of the process.Itrsquos a young group with loads of growth to come. Wersquoll keep building towards that.ldquoThey want to make the  or  thousand people, as well as everyone watching at home, proud every time they pull on the jersey.ldquoItrsquos a great group to work with.

title: glasgow-bin-strike-residents-told-store-rubbish-homes-next-collection-day
story: Guidance issued by Glasgow City Council has advised householders to keep rubbish in their homes " they can" or to store it outsidethey cannot - but only after wrapping the waste in two orthree bags.The strike by binmen, who are seeking better pay and conditions, has led to a waste crisis with overflowing bins and missed collections across the city.:Trade union hits out after Susan Aitken plays down rat incidents as minor contactThe directions to store waste at home applies to all of Glasgows residents, but is likely to hit hardest for those whose properties have a main door and kerbside collection for rubbish.This group mdash around  per cent of Glasgow households, or almost one-in-three mdash have a three-week collection cycle and some have just missed their latest household waste pick-up.This means some of Glasgows wealthier residents will have six weeks of accumulated rubbish to store either in or around their property by the time it is collected.The waste crisis has led to rubbish piling upThe guidance published by Glasgow City Council states: "If bins for general waste become full, please store your waste at homeyou can."If you cant store your rubbish within your home, please double or triple bag this waste before placing it next to the general bins you use, either in a communal bin area or by your own home."Please avoid using recycling bins for general waste as this may lead to further delays in those bins being collected."Flat and tenements have general waste collected every  days. General waste is collected from high-rise blocks every four days.: Second wave of action could run up to ChristmasEight days of strike action came to a close on Monday night. However,workers have demanded a fresh strike ballot against their employer over low pay.The GMB union has now warned it could meana second wave of strikes could hit cleansing services in Scotlandrsquos biggest city in the run-up to Christmas.

title: green-scotland-cop26-climate-investigation-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive accessas we look to answer the pressing questions in Scotlands climate crisis fight.As the COP conference looms on the horizon, we will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate on this crucial topic.Find out more about our exclusive pound for two months offer here.From the hundreds of sites and big-name companies that broke environmental rules, to the most polluted streets in Scotland, readers can expectground-breaking exclusives, in-depth analysis, and interactive content ndash as well as regular live videos, giving you the chance to speak directly with the award-winning reporters behind the stories.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just pound for two monthshere.More than  industrial sites across Scotland have been officially damned as ldquounsatisfactory on pollution, according to data from the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyseen by The Ferret.Sepa assessed the environmental performance of two big oilcompanies, ExxonMobil and Ineos, as ldquovery poor in . A Grangemouth chemical plant and a Coupar Angus chicken processor were rated as ldquopoor.Read the full exclusive report here.More than one in ten of Scotlandrsquos fish farms have been rated as ldquounsatisfactory" by the Scottish Governmentrsquos environmental watchdog because of pollution, pesticide and reporting breaches, wecan today reveal.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhas assessed over  of some  salmon farms around the coast as either ldquovery poor, ldquopoor or ldquoat risk because they broke, or threatened to break, environmental rules in .The exclusive revelations can be read here in full.WE can today reveal the top sitesacrossScotland that have been officiallydeemed "unsatisfactory" on pollution by Scotlands environmental watchdog.The ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencydamnedthe performance of more than  sitesincluding Trump Turnberry, Ineos, and Faslane nuclear base.View the full interactive map of sites here.More than , of Scotlands wildle species and natural habitats are in a "poor" condition, and dozens of the nationrsquos protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we can reveal.Ahead of the COP conference in Glasgow, our joint investigation with The Ferret reveals that  habitats and  species inScotlandare in poor condition. We also found that climate change has impacted  protected sites and  natural features.Read the full exclusive report here.DOZENS of Scotlands protected sites have been damaged byclimate change, we canreveal today.The long term decline of Scotlandrsquos wildle was documented in a report in  called the State of Nature which claimed one in nine species - including kittiwakes and wildcats - was threatened with extinction.View the full map here.MORE than  habitats and  species inScotlandare in "poor" condition, we can reveal.Environmental and wildle groups are calling for urgent action to combat the twinclimate changeand wildle crises and help preserve Scotlandrsquos natural heritage.View the list in full here.Almost a third of Scotlandrsquos streets have higher levels of toxic particle air pollution than they did before the Covid- pandemic, analysis can reveal.#The ldquoappalling findings show the levels of air pollution caused by small particles ndash known as particulate matter and#largely due to traffic pollution ndash increased in  per cent of average readings taken this year, when compared with data from .View the full exclusive report here.Air pollution is to be the subject of a Scotland-wide investigation ndash the first to be carried out by the countrys new environmental watchdog, we can reveal.EnvironmentStandards Scotland , an independent body which came into force on  October to oversee environmental law post-Brexit, confirmed the "intractable issue" which has plagued Scotland for ldquoover a decade would be the focus of its first major piece of work.Read the full story here.The traffic is at a standstill on Atholl Street in the centre of Perth, cars, trucks and buses running their engines as they wait for the lights to change.##For years this city street ndash#with its mixture of shops, cafes and homes ndash#has been amongst Scotlandrsquos most polluted due to levels of particulate matter . Nitrogen dioxide readings are as high as many on the streets of Scotlandrsquos biggest cities. Exposure to high levels of both pollutants has been linked to increased risk ofhealthconditions like asthma, strokes and even dementia.#Read the full case study here.In an open letter to the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, published as part of our joint investigation, over  leadinghealthprofessionals ndash including consultants, GPs and medical academics ndash are calling for more action to be taken on air pollution to save lives.Councils must enforce laws, they say, air monitoring should be increased, including outside schools, while the Scottish Government should invest more heavily in active travel, publictransportand green infrastructure.Read the letter in full here.Scotlandrsquos rivers, lochs, canals and burns are in the worst state on record, with more than  damaged by pollution and other problems, according to the latest official analysis.New assessment methods used by the ScottishEnvironmentProtection Agencyhave more than doubled the number of waterways classied as ldquobad between  and . There are ldquosignicant environmental problems caused by a number of pressures, Sepa said.Read the full exclusive report here.SCOTLANDS worst rivers, lochs, canals and burns for pollution have been revealed in new analysis of official watchdog data.Amongst the many rivers rated as either bad or poor by Sepa are some of Scotlandrsquos most well-known. They include long stretches of the Almond, Carron, Dee, Don, Earn, Esk, Kelvin, Lossie, Nairn, Nith, Spey, Tay, Tummel, and Water of Leith.Find how your local river or loch ranks using our interactive toolNearly  sites run by Scottish Water including sewage and wastewater treatment are ldquopoor, ldquovery poor or ldquoat risk, according to Scotlandrsquos environmental watchdog.Almost all these ldquounsatisfactory sites are considered to be among Scotlandrsquos critical national infrastructure ndash operations deemed essential for the state to deliver vital public services.Read the full story here.Today, we reveal the Scottish Government has missed its targets on reducing climate emissions in five of the seven sectors set out in its  plan to tackle climate change.Environmental activists said the missed targets painted a ldquodisappointing picture of widespread failure on emissions reductions. They worry that static or increasing annual emissions in key sectors mean Scotland risks squandering good progress made in other areas.Read the full exclusive report here.The Scottish Government must take ldquoradical action on green job creation and ending fuel povertyit is to achieve a Just Transition to net-zero carbon emissions, trade unions sayThe Scottish low carbon economy provided , jobs in , the most recent data available, a nearly five per cent decrease from . It was also fewer than the , roles provided by the sector in .Read the story in full here.
